review_title: It is tough work, sometimes with little praise, but the benefits and pay outweigh the negatives.
pros:
Getting to work outside is a plus. 
Responsible for route.
Primarily working alone, if that is your desire.
Excellent benefits that cannot be matched anywhere else.
cons:
Long hours during the Christmas season make it difficult to spend extra time with family.
Family is often not a priority, depending on the mentality of supervisors and/or center managers.
Long hot days in the summer.

pros: If you look hard enough you’ll find people who are good at what they do and willing to help you when you need it.  Many people at UPS are loyal to the company and stick around for a very long time.  They are usually a wealth of UPS information in various divisions and products.
cons: There is a malaise about many people both in the union and in management.  This may come from lack of incentive to be productive, boredom, and/or a dull work environment.  If there was a general push to reward people on merit more often and seniority less often, this could be changed.

review_title: UPS has been a great learning experience for me, the job provides a hard work environment, good pay, and great benefits!
pros: I work the pre-load shift and it supplies: 3.5 hours of a fast-past/steady shift, good pay, and amazing benefits.
cons: The cons to my position are that it requires you to wake up early in the mornings and it is a very labor intensive job. If you don't like to be challenged daily... I wouldn't recommend this job to you.

pros: Fairly safe during recession.  Few were let go due to slow down.
cons:
New in 2014, if your spouse works and their employer offers ANY health benefits, your spouse is ineligible for medical benefits through UPS (Management Only).  Even if the coverage is poor or very expensive.  Also new; smoking management OR their smoking spouse are surcharged $1800.00 per year for either one or both.  No change for Union employees.
Aside from the drivers, few in UPS have full time positions.  Not much room for advancement unless you go into management and lose to ability to cover your spouse.

review_title: For such a big company, you would think your experience would be much better. Is not RUN!
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Maspeth, NY
pros:
Good starting pay. Monday-friday not bad.
Hours are okay... and some people say it has good benefits. ...... other thn that is not a good job.
cons: Very fast pace. Even if it's not your fault ... it still your fault when something goes wrong. Don't do it not worth the stress. You better off as an hourly thn a part time supervisor. You have to put in ur 10 min break, but u dnt get to take it. Management frown upon break time for a supervisor.

review_title: Great for Financial Stability, Horrible for Family & Life
pros: Money will not be a major concern if you decide to work for this company. Stock options are ok (FT Management and above) and the stability of not worrying about layoffs are great pro's with any company.
cons: Did you ever hear the old saying, "money can't buy happiness?" Well, it's true! They will pay you at a competitive wage rate for the job "description", but will ask for MUCH MUCH more from you physically and mentally. Example: They will require you (at management level and above) to MEMORIZE numerous pages of what they call "Safety Material" then recall at any moment. If you have a character out of place or not memorized EXACTLY how it was written, your job and livelihood will be threatened. Over the years they have taken more and more from the management side (Removing spouses from benefits, raising costs of benefits, requiring a $150/month fee for smokers.. just to name a few) while the union side experiences none of these changes. Ever heard of a vacation? Sure, but guess what, blackout dates from Nov through Dec. Restricted to 2 weeks in the summer (Oh, they call summer May 1st - September 15), and you can't take a vacation when someone else is off. Lastly, the conditions are horrible. When it's 13 degrees outside, it's 14 degrees inside and maybe 30 degrees in the office. Have you ever tried to type up reports with frostbitten fingers? Again, ask any employee or management person working for them to verify... heck, they can even wear a thermostat or temp gauge. They are all told, "The building is set at 45 degrees". What's left out is that, sure it's 45 degrees....near the heater which is located 25ft in the air! The floor will be well below FREEZING!

review_title: Great job, if you can hack it...
pros:
Great money! £9.07 an hour on a temp contract with a pay increase to ~£14/h after first three months. 

Great hours! I'm on the 3:30 -7:30 shift in the morning, which in practice is more like 3 - 8, and providing you don't mind the early hours it's great! 

Great workout! The 4 hours of heavy lifting combined with my circa 4 mile bike ride each way every day means I'm getting fitter by the day! No need for that gym membership anymore!

Great People! So far everyone is friendly, and even when things get tough and your supervisor starts shouting at you (It can happen during the really bad days) you know it's never meant maliciously. You might get thrown in at the deep end like I did when I first started, especially if they're several people short, but you are praised for hard work. =)

From what I hear there are plenty of opportunities to further your career at UPS, evidenced from people I have spoken to!
cons:
Can be quite daunting during your first few weeks. The way out is especially scary because they have tighter security than at the airport! X-ray scanners, metal detectors, you name it! Understandable of course, but still...

The system used (On pre-load anyway) is utter rubbish. They force all the parcels down the belt at you like there's going to be some sort of famine and take no care if you get buried under a pile of parcels. 

Even if you are the most caring person in the world you will eventually stop giving a crap about handling parcels carefully. Everyone chucks and tosses things about. Okay, maybe the obviously fragile stuff they wont, but little parcels are just thrown willy nilly.

review_title: A strong salary coupled with competitive benefits is unable to balance against this production driven stressful workplac
pros: Salary/benefits are good.  There are some great people to work with here.  Company has a long history and thus is expected to be around for quite some time.
cons: Hours 60 per week gauranteed.  Production goals have gotten overly aggressive in the past few years.  The company has become reactive instead of proactive

pros: Good company super structure.  Good base pay structure and some excellent job perks ( or benefits).  They have a lot of partnerships with other companies and the employee stock structure is very good.
cons: Job expectations are insultingly unrealistic, coupled with a complete in ability to have the power and authority to excercise good/excellent/ or intelligent solutions.  I have seen A supervisor start work at 1am.  and they were still working at 7pm.  that is an 18 hr shift.. Thats about $11.50 an hour.  Drivers also tend to make more than their direct reports.

pros:
Great benefits
No weekends
Paid Holidays
Employee discounts
Pension
Free CDLTraining and company pays for CDL Test
cons: Little room for advancment. Full time and positions that pay are rare and difficult to obtain unless you want to obtain a CDL. The biggest con with UPS is the International Brotherhood of Teamsters which keep the company from managing effectively, creates an unsafe enviornment, because acident prone employees cannot be fired and are very rarely diciplined. Teamsters also frown upon hard working employees and only represent those that go against the company.

pros: You can get amazing benefits that even a person who works for major companies will be jealous of what you receive. I get better benefits than most people I know plus you can receive discounts on items you buy.
cons: Possibility of injury is extremely high and in-order to have work pay for injury you must be on the clock. If you get hurt at work and you're not on the clock then you must pay out of your own pocket.

pros: You don't sit around all day and once you finish it feels like you accomplished something. You're thrown in pretty quickly so you learn fast and other things seem easy.
cons: Only part time until you can work up seniority to get a full time position. For those that like a more sedentary job, this isn't for you.

pros: You will get some hours depending on if they need you. Not much else positive i can say about that. Pay isn't good, also dont get Lunches like you're supposed to.
cons: Here people are Dispensable, not really important at all to Middle Management. The signs posted talking about Depression i didn't understand until after a couple weeks, this is not a good place to grow a career or One's Self

pros:
1.  The HR Department was extremely helpful in both the interview and onboarding process.

2.  The work was physical but still required you to think.  You were shown how to do the work and then turned loose.  Someone was always available if you had questions.

3.  Representing the UPS brand was a pleasure.  It was eye opening to see part of the process that takes that little box from the shipper to my front door.
cons:
I really enjoyed the work and would like to work for this company full time.  However, to break in to the full time arena you may have to work in the package handling warehouse from 4 to 5 years on a part time basis.  If you are just starting out. the benefits available and the long term payoff would be more than worth it.

I was also surprised at the negative attitude of a number of the drivers who were full time.  Complaining was pretty constant.  Treatment of packages that had to be returned to the distribution center was often poor at best.  These are individuals with a great wage for the area and a benefit package that appeared to be much better than what I had while on active duty.  They need to recognize what they have!

pros: Great pay great people and great place to work. You can work 8 hours with no lunch and leave work 30 minutes early instead. I'm sure OSHA won't like it but for me was great
cons: After peak season they let you go with no courtesy to say at least today is your last day.

review_title: They need to retool the workforce structure
pros: OK pay for little qualification, engaging work, learn a lot, culture of caring
cons: Inability to move from PT to FT without YEARS of working there. Management often works with "theoretical" capacity for workload, doesn't take into account things like weather, revolving employees, software issues etc outside of a supervisor's control

pros: Once you qualify for the benefits, they are great. Particularity for a part-time worker. If you are in school some location payout to help cover tuition.
cons: The atmosphere can be very aggressive. If you do well you are going to get more work and less breaks than if you do badly. The pre-loaders are treated the worst and high turn over is expected which perpetuates all the already existent problems. It takes a year before benefits kick in.

review_title: Definately not for everyone, absolutely perfect for others

Amazing place to be part of.  Couldn't imagine doing anything else.  Comrodery with co-workers is great,.  Blue collar, hard work for great pay kind of place.  You'll know pretty quick if it's for you.

review_title: (PT Preload). It's Okay. Wouldn't make it a career.
pros:
Main Details:

Orientation is every week from Tuesday - Friday. The pay is $10.20 per hr for Orientation week only then $11 once you start. 

For PT, pay is $11 per hr and overtime is time and a half ($16.50) after working for more than 5 hours straight. 

I work in SPA (Scan, print &apply) and work as a sorter afterward if need be. Thursday is payday.  

Work varies from either M-F or Tue-Sat. 

Double shifts can be worked (based upon seniority) for both Twilight and Preload.

Off holidays unless you sign up for them. Seniority rules. 

Everything is team based.
cons:
High standards. 

Breaks are only 10 min, everyone takes the break at the same time. Only one break. 

Takes time to learn the facility layout. Will take about 2-3 weeks to fully learn it. 

Supervisors are a hit or miss, IMO. YMMV. Some are better than others.

No live checks. Direct deposit or this debit card that your earnings are loaded into. 

DO NOT BE LATE. THEY WILL HAND YOUR BUTT ON A PLATTER FOR IT. If you're not there at least 5 minutes early HR will yell. I cannot stress this enough. Clocking in at 3:27 for a 3:30 shift will get you shouted at. 

No consistent start/end times, at least for preload. Start times (so far) can be as early as 2:45a to as late as 3:30a, depending on facility needs. 3:30a-8a is a general guideline at best. Some may leave as late as 10a.

If you work SPA, keep hands moisturized. After a full week of working my pointer finger is bleeding from sticking labels onto thousands of boxes.  Invest in good quality gloves for when you get called to sort.

cons: Supervisors are cockroaches, bad starting pay, treated as a number in the system, overworked, when the manager isn't there expect to stay an extra hour, times vary, seniority rules, don't expect to have a life during the week after work.

pros:
Only corporate location jobs have pros to their positions.
Insurance is good.
cons: Majority jobs are part-time and do not pay basic bills but during peak season, you are expected to do any and all warehouse jobs as requested. It's like the military. Company touts promotions from within but nepotism is alive and well, most positions in warehouses aren't posted and it's a dead-end job for most employees. Senior management are all afraid of being moved to remote locations so they manage by belittling and being rude for fear of not producing acceptable numbers on ridiculous reports.

job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in Bradenton, FL
pros: Lots of opportunities for movement and lots of career paths to suit the way you work.
cons:
Stressful (either physical or mental) work with weird hours. 

Company will leave you in bad situations if you don’t articulate displeasure with them. I’ve been working over a year a single part time supervisor on a two supervisor operation even after asking multiple times for a secondary supervisor.

pros: Ok benefits, gym, cafeteria, kuerigs. Ok pay. You do not go out to peak.
cons: Being an admin here basically means you do the work no one wants to do. It doesn't matter that you are "just an admin" you will be asked to handle questions, situations, and reports above your paid grade because you "own" the reports you do. Mind you we aren't properly trained on the purpose of each report or explained what they are for. You are only acknowledged when you make a mistake. Admins are treated as the low of the low even though you are normally helping everyone. We aren't even given laptops but contact workers or interns, temp employees are given laptops. As an admin you first accrue your discretionary time however after a certain time you get it at the beginning of the year although your vacation is still accrued. Everyone above you gets to arrive and leave at their leisure. Using work time to go to the gym while you have to sit at your desk and arrive before everyone and usually leave after. The location for the corporate office is horrible. There is some management who let their employees leave work earlier to beat the traffic but that is if you have a laptop and /or you are under certain management teams. I don't feel there is much development for admins. High divorce rate.

pros:
Great full time pay with few employment requirements. Go from dirt poor to 100k/year in less time than it takes to get a degree, and paid for your efforts!

Massive hiring push in most areas as facilities expand and volume swells.
cons:
The PT journey to a FT job can be an underpaid struggle, especially since amazon currently pays better for the same work. 

 Management relations — with a need to impress superiors by “improving” work groups, supervisors often have nothing better to do than to find reasons for disciplining employees.

review_title: Really great job to have for peak season
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Asheville, NC
pros:
Pretty fun job to have for a month or two. You get to be outside and stay active, and every driver I worked with was super chill and down to earth. Plus, just about every person you interact with is happy to see you. Was paid well and (for the most part) given plenty of hours. I voluntarily worked some Saturday shifts but I don't think we as helpers had any mandatory ones. 

None of the rumors I had heard about (such as paying a ridiculous amount in union fees) were true at the Asheville, NC location.  The dress code requirements were simple and didn't require any extra purchases on my part.

If you're an active, athletic person you'll find that it's not as physically draining or as hard on your body as you'd expect. If you're not in great shape, this job might help you fix that. 

No micromanaging and nobody breathing down your neck. You very rarely interact with anybody at UPS aside from the drivers.
cons:
Not enough trucks for peak season. Felt like we were understaffed or the facility was too small. A few of the routes I had to work with needed to use Budget trucks which is a huge hassle (at least it gets you more hours). Expect an atmosphere full of frustration during peak season. 

Not much of a con in my opinion, but some people might think it is: sometimes you don't know your schedule until the day of. However, that was made well-known to me before accepting the job, and in my case turned out to be more of the exception than the rule. 

The appearance guidelines (clean-shaven, no visible tattoos, etc.) are a bit silly but not a big deal for a temporary job.

review_title: Team leader on PM Shift (Warehouse duties)
pros: there operations link both office duties and warehouse floor duties which together enables the employee to have more knowledge of logistics across a broader field.
cons: Split shifts seem to be an on going issue for potential employees who have valuable logistics experience. Simply put,  future candidates for roles within the warehouse operations sector will not apply as the shifts are often split between early mornings and evening times which does not suit many candidates.

pros:
Union Benefits
Some Decent Co-Workers
Otherwise there aren't many. The warehouses are a fast-paced nightmare.
cons: No solid Job Description, When you are part of the Warehouse you get bounced around to any area that needs help, and with how this place is run you will always be shortstaffed. Work comes hard and fast and if the Full Time Supervisors don't have you on their Radar forget about any sort of recognition.

pros:
$18/hr for part time supervisor job
Willing to promote people in their 20s
High compensation in full time positions
cons:
Company culture is not good. UPS essentially rotates metrics that they care about on any given month and they crack whips down the hierarchy to achieve goals. 
Evaluation is a joke and my primary beef with the company.  I enjoyed the job for a short time pursuing goals but soon learned that the evaluation process is not taken seriously and that I essentially had no incentive to be exceptional. 
Was asked by a person in management “You know you’re a white male right” when I asked if any positions were open.

pros: The healthcare benefits are really good. Supportive coworkers and direct management.
cons: Workload can be really heavy sometimes (10-13 hours). Corporate makes all important decision  without letting people aware.  Shrinking benefits every years during the 3 years I had been working for the company. The latest move that they made without telling anyone is that they are "shipping" jobs to a third party and laying off people. Some people I know had put in half their life for the company but still let go to save cost...pension, 401k gone just like that.

job_title: Driver Helper in East Petersburg, PA
pros:
The driver helper job is a great part time income before Christmas. The pay is alright at $15/hr and the job is easy. You just run to the door step and that's it.

More importantly, the drivers get paid well because the Teamsters Union makes it that way. They start at $21/hr while Amazon drivers start at $15/hr. That is the difference a union makes.
cons: The seat driver helpers have isn't even a real seat. It is a sort of padded board that you fold down and sit on. When sitting on it, it is best to let your body sway with the vehicle because even though it feels like you might fall off, you won't, and if you hold tight to the board you're sitting on, it puts more strain on your back.

pros: Good wages and benifits was great company to work for 20 years ago when they actally took pride in the company
cons: Ever since UPS went public with there stock they dont want to  spend money on anything. Took away all employees little perks that we did have even afterposting a 71% more prfit then last year and are keeping many people on layoff so they dont have to pay them

pros: Challenging work. Good people.  Somewhat stable.

They are so concerned with internal measures they can't see the forest through the trees and end up walking over dollars to save nickles.  Too bad.   UPS has turned into a job instead of a career.

pros: Very solid company.  MIP (Management Incentive Plan) is generally a nice bonus of stock and cash given in December.  Time off is competitive to other companies for time served.

pros: It's a great job, I get to be out and about all day. I love the constant moving, before you know it, it's time to go home.

I am used to getting extra hours during the holidays and I expected the same working for UPS but they don't allow it. Other than that. I love the job.

review_title: Though difficult labor, working at UPS can offer benefits, advancement possibilites and educational help.
pros:
Part time employees have, in the past, been granted access to the same benefits that drivers receive, including health, dental, vision, life insurance, legal, and pension related benefits.  Dental, for instance, is covered without even a co-pay, though the health has minimal ones.  In Washington State, there's a choice between Blue Cross Blue Shield and Aetna for the health and dental as of last year.  Domestic partnerships are covered as well, and so far without flaw in my experience, within the state by UPS.  The extension of benefits are generous in scope, and are rare this day in age, thanks to Union bargaining.  

It used to take years to advance beyond a part time position to a driving position, but within at least the Redmond, Washington Hub (and likely Seattle and Everett Hubs as well), advancement to a driving position takes a year or less based on seniority - in the past, it took four or five years at times, as they are good jobs.  However, part time employee retention is very low (over 100% attrition per year), so advancing in seniority is quick.  With displays of competence, changing positions within the part time fields is easy as well - from Loader to Unloader, Irregulars, Smalls, Sorting, etc, are transitions usually with little wait time, and often add some additional pay ($1/h additional for Sorting, for example). 

Attendance policies for Part Time Union work is very lax - for Loader/Unloaders especially, no-call no-show events are rarely punished, in order to retain employees.  Supervisors are at the opposite spectrum, and can expect to be fired for a similar event, or even strongly discouraged for calling in sick.  After a year, sick days amount to a week's worth, along with a week of "Option" days which can be taken just like sick days, and two weeks of vacation, even for part time employees.  You can expect not to be allowed to take vacation or option days towards the end of the year, during busy season.  For Part Time employees, labor past 5 hours is considered overtime, and you're provided one 15 minute break, or two if overtime extends particularly far.  Lunches are optional, but unpaid, and are typically not taken by part timers at all.  

College tuition help for Part Time union employees is at $3,000 from the Earn and Learn program, which comes in the form of grants.  However, they seem no longer to be tax exempt - yet in the past, personal experience has seen the full sums granted without issue.  This involves registering what classes you wished to take online via the Earn and Learn website, and at the end of the quarter, faxing your info to them, basically a statement of your grades and the costs.  If approved, you receive a check up to $1,500 dollars a quarter, to a maximum of $3,000 per year, for as many as four years.  Similarly, loans are available which, so long as you continue to work at UPS, will see their principal paid off by UPS itself.  If you leave, expect to pay the whole thing back - and either way, you do have to pay the interest on the loans as well.  The interest is very high, 14% or more, and you should expect to pay more in interest than in the principal by the end of the loan term.  This seems to be handled by Wells Fargo Bank, at least in Washington state.  

Another minor perk, at least when doing a job like Loading, Unloading, or Sorting packages, is the permission to wear personal music players and listen to them.  One headphone should be off one ear, but otherwise you're free to fill what is otherwise repetitive work with books on tape, music, radio, etc, so long as you can still hear when being called.  This, of course, does not apply if you advance to management, and the trucks do not have radios. 

Safe working records are rewarded to whole shifts of work by BBQs of increasing scale the longer a safe run occurs, wherein free hamburgers, hot dogs, chips, soda, etc, are provided at the end of a shift.  Awards theoretically go out monthly for best work group members, and best shift member, but this happens unpredictably as well.  The schemes for rewarding employees or work groups based on performance has varied widely in the two years I've been employed, and sometimes are non-existent.  They range from sports drinks to pizza parties, depending on the time period and achievement, though consistency is not to be expected.
cons:
An immediate warning for new workers - under a new contract, in effect after August 2008, it takes much longer for you to receive health coverage (formerly 1 month), and even longer for your family (formerly 1 month as well, now a year).  The new contract does not increase starting rates (minimum wage or $8.50, whichever is higher), but will increase wages with experience much quicker than before (to at least $16 an hour top, higher depending on the job, in a couple of years).  The Health Coverage is identical, but now handled under a different contract, setting the stage for the stripping of benefits under future contracts. 

Contracts are voted on by all Union Members, but Drivers are much more likely to vote than Part Time employees, leading to lopsided contracts.  Wages were stagnant for a very long time for Part Time employees - if they had grown with inflation since 1980, they would be $20/h or higher.  Driving positions, however, are much better compensated, and especially with overtime can support middle class families.  

Part time work is physically demanding and exposed to the environment as well.  There is not air conditioning in the summer, and heating during the winter is either only at a few select places, or completely exposed to the environment by open bay doors.  Trailers themselves are often wet, snowy, and filthy.  Packages can be heavy, dirty, and dangerous - for example, whole anchors, points unshielded, are sent with nothing more than a tag with a UPS label upon it.  You should expect to wear gloves which will leave your hands wet by sealing in moisture, or suffer cuts and abrasions in addition to callouses.  You should expect to have to provide your own boots, or be berated - they will not prevent you from working, but they will find ways to goad you into wearing them, such as denying you gloves until you purchase boots.

Ultimately, the lacking pay, poor conditions, demanding labor, late night hours, and now long-delayed benefits encourage a turnover rate which, at Redmond Night Sort, was well over 100% per year, and likely to get worse so long as the contract remains as is.  Which may mean it will be very easy for anyone to find work there, though most will and do quit.  

Advancing to other positions means increasing regimentation as well - UPS is notable as a company for firing employees if they fail to keep a clean desk, if they are white collar, as discussed in Eric Abrahamson and David H. Freeman's book, "A Perfect Mess".  This mentality seems to follow through to the lower levels, though enforcement is somewhat lax, and tightens at the upper levels of employment.  Certain policies are announced from time to time which are never rescinded, but only enforced briefly - they're forgotten about once they prove ineffective or counterproductive, which they almost always seem to be.  Expect regular tests and memorization of safety mnemonics, such as the "Eight Keys to Lifting and Lowering" or "Five Keys to Preventing Slips and Falls".

pros:
The benefits are, by far, the best reason to work for UPS.  There are very few employers out there that offer part-time employees such good benefits.  Another benefit is that you know the hours you will be working everyday.  The preload always runs Mon - Fri and you are almost always done with work by 9:30 AM.  This allows you to be very flexible during the day if you desire to hold a second job, or attend classes.

The job itself is not that difficult.  Although, it does require tough skin sometimes to deal with the whining and complaining from preloaders with a poor work ethic or drivers who complain about the quality of their load.
cons:
The hours are one of the benefits, but one of the drawbacks as well.  It is a hard adjustment for some people to get up at 3:00 AM to go to work.  Also, starting pay is not that great.  Oftentimes, preloaders that you supervise who have worked at UPS for several years will be making more than you.

If you take a part-time management position with the hopes of getting promoted to full-time, well, good luck.  UPS has always treated me well, but from the day I started I have been told that there are promotional opportunities.  If you take the job for extra work, then that's great.  If you want to make UPS a career, then seek out the positions that are full-time and apply for them directly.  They need part-timers to run the day to day operations, so some managers don't really want to help people develop a career with UPS because then they would have to find someone to replace you.

review_title: a few rules at ups that you wont find other places
job_title: Operations Supervisor in Willow Grove, PA
pros:
Rule #1 If you are a worker, seniority is king. Time is the only limit to your growth potential. Eventually you will be offered a job as a package car driver, Feeder driver or full time hub (processing center) job. (just don't have anything on your driving record in the last 3 years otherwise you will need to wait until it drops off)
Time is the only limit, its a union job, 

Rule #2 In management, schooling is king. if you want to go anywhere in management you NEED to be in school. Even the low level managers who only work 25-30 hours a week must be in school (they don't care if you have a degree, you need to be GETTING a degree, either another one or a more advanced one). If you are not in school, do not even bother, you will NEVER go anywhere in management. That being said UPS offers tuition reimbursement up to 20k dollars spread out over 5 years.



This company will NEVER go away. The focus on maintaining growth, profitability and sustainability borderlines on obsession. 

3 The company loves getting womans and minority magazine awards "Best place for advancement" NAACP, so if you are a minority or a woman, you have a leg up on the competition. (especially if you are a minority woman!)

Quit your gym membership, we PAY you to work out in here.

In General, only the very very best managers/supervisors get promoted past the part time level. Your boss will be organized, competent and very much a go-getter. Also in general, He or She will work hard to develop you to the level needed to move up -- so long as you show the attitude, aptitude (good numbers in current assignment), ability to take and use constructive criticism and drive to succeed no matter what -- and that you are in school.
^ have all those ducks in a row and in general you will eventually get somewhere.


A list of employee discounts that no company outside the Fortune 50 will be able to give you.
the top 4 wireless companies all have UPSER discounts, as do many of the top auto makers (Ford etc.) there are many discounts that ups has negotiated for its workers.
cons:
Rule #1 It might be ALOT of time. Some facilities have wait lists of over 10 years to go full time package car driving, longer for feeders and A22.3 (full time inside/inside -- working in the processing center for 8 hours) What you can do is find out when the building was opened. There will be waves of retirement every 30 or so years and if you get in during one of these the wait time can drop quite low (people with as little time in as one year were getting calls 7-8 years ago.)

The jobs are all very physical. You will always be paid 100% of your hourly wage, and the expectation is you will give 100% of your effort, this is not a job where you will be able to chit chat with your coworkers as you work, its ready set go! and GO GO GO until you are done. -- There is ALWAYS work to be done.


Rule #2 The company loves getting accolades for being a great place for women and minorities to advance in management (so long as they are in school). This may mean that if you aren't a woman or minority that someone less qualified than you gets one of the ever elusive Full time management opportunities - just because you are a white male and they are not. UPS has quotas.

Some of the long time upsers are a bit disillusioned that even 20 years later they are still expected to GO GO GOOO!!! and give 100%, 100% of the time, and aren't as able to do it as they used to be. Many of these guys and gals and even those with less time have no problem Back-talking right to a manager they do not respect right in front of everyone else if they think so-and-so isn't working as hard as they are. (and everyone is always working harder than everyone else) 
Sometimes the managers really do need to be an @$$hole just to keep people in line. If you can't do that or even wear a mask that allows you to, don't go management.

review_title: Great benefits, but seniority rules tend to reward times spent over actual work.
job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in Orlando, FL

cons: Whenever the company and Teamster's Union can decide on a contract the benefits are great. Unfortunately if you are a hard working individual you will be used constantly to pull the slack of those who just show up for the benefits and a little extra money. The Union allows for employees to work as little as possible and maintain their position. There are times when employees have held a job after not reporting to work after an entire month or more. Management has not been strong in their effort to motivate workers and make them aware of their rights or the consequences of taking advantage of the system. Because of this the workforce is unstable and unbalanced. Credibility and integrity are values that are rare on all levels of employment. Working conditions are awful. Facilities are just barely holding together and the filth is left to pile up in all areas. Under staffing is a real issue as well. The company does not like to put people in positions outside of what they have already done. So if you are an operations employee expect to remain in the operation as a supervisor manager and so on.

review_title: UPS Is good for the money!
pros: If you are into politics, you will go far; Drivers can make upwards of 90k a year after three years; Full time supervisors and managers (above supervisors) make about 75k-150+k, respectively.
cons: No upward progression if you don't play the game of politics; most management will not help you advance; the bottom line is the only thing that matters; most supervisor's have absolutely no leadership ability.

review_title: An okay place if you just need any job.
pros: The job itself can be fun, working in and around airplanes. Moving boxes and aircraft cargo containers around makes for a great workout. Consistent schedule, all weekends and major holidays off.
cons: Lifers/high seniority workers tend to slack off. It is a union company, which for me is a con because I see plenty of lazy workers that simply can't be fired. The only upward mobility is either to become a driver of become a supervisor. Supervisors can only do so much, and their frustration shows often. Pay is not nearly enough for this to be your only form of income.

review_title: Extremely difficult place from a physical and mental standpoint - almost impossible to work 20 or 30 years there.
job_title: Package Car Driver in Worcester, MA
pros: Salary and benefit package.  Unmatched in the delivery industry.  The work does give you a boost physically in the beginning, but that disappears as your your body starts to breakdown from the relentless labor.
cons: Hostile work environment.  Long hours and heavy labor that ruin any time off you might have.  Impossible to start or maintain personal relationships at this company.  Alcoholism and divorce is rampant.

review_title: Crazy Place to Work Can Be Fun/Awful
pros:
I worked on both the preload and unload shifts. I then became a shift supervisor. This is the best job for a college kid, as UPS will help with tuition and books if you become a supervisor.

UPS is a crazy place to work. It is loud, dirty and incredibly unsafe despite everyone's best efforts. The pay is low, the benefits are great and after working there being in the corporate world was a breeze. A great job to teach someone patience, motivational skills, negotiation and how to suck it up and take one for the team. It kind of has a half high school clique/half paramilitary structure. All in all a great experience for a young adult. If you're over 25 you will probably hate it.

During the holidays you can pretty much make as much as you like as a package handler. You hit overtime easily as a part timer and will be making a ton just riding in a truck running packages to doors. Be prepared to alter your lifestyle, as getting up at 3:00am takes some adjustment. The morning paid a little more then the evening, plus you were done for the week at 10am on Fridays.

- benefits package (many people work there just for the insurance)
- insane nutjobs that you will meet on this job 
- good workout without gym membership
- free turkey at Thanksgiving
- flexible hours (great for college)
cons:
- incredibly stressful when belts jam, people don't show up or during holiday seasons
- very high Teamster dues and no benefits until you put in a certain amount of hours (about a year IIRC)
- insane nutjobs that you will meet on this job (what kind of non-student gets up at 3:00am every day for a part time job!)
- Union pay scale. I literally made the same money as a junior in college as a kid that was illiterate and couldn't split the belt and a mentally challenged guy who walked the mis-sorts the illiterate kid missed back to the start of the belt.
- constantly yelled at by everyone (you get used to it).

Teamsters will demand dues but don't expect anyone to go to bat for you.

job_title: Package Dispatch Supervisor in Florence, SC
pros:
-Good pay and benefits
-Very good training
-Recognized as a good launch pad for a career
cons:
-No matter what you do, it isn't good enough
-Things don't slow down for any kind of work condition
-There is a lot of, "Do as I say, not as I do." 
-It is a team atmosphere where you pick up whatever your team mate can't (or most cases won't) get done, but usually the person that is actually willing to work gets everything shoved on them.  Lack of discipline all around.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Aberdeen, SD
pros: can't give start date just that It will happen when it does. Can't start till I get a uniform but the uniforms have to be found and then sent here none kept locally.
cons: low pay for our area, hard work. No profit sharing for part-timers or temp employees. They do offer 401-K not my cup of tea but it does exist.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Generally the people are all pleasant. It is a job where you definitely get a good workout. It is fast-paced and if you are willing to take on more responsibilities and strive to always do a good job you will be given every opportunity to do so. The benefits are wonderful and cover anything that could possibly go wrong even if you are just a part time worker. The pay gradually increases and has the potential to be very sustaining if you stay around for a long time. Opportunity to advance in the company to a driver is readily available at our center, maybe not a full time driver immediately but you will be given the opportunity to try to drive if you do your time and you work hard so that the management takes you into consideration.
cons: Unfortunately, outside of peak our center does not keep enough people on staff -or- they do not push everyone on the staff to balance the work appropriately. They do take advantage of the harder workers (floaters) and let them handle all the slack in the building. Also, it feels to me like the people who think that UPS pays wonderfully do not pay attention to the fact they are being really screwed if they are just in it for the money during the first several years while waiting to be a driver. People say "Management sucks, don't enter it" but if your entire ambition is to just be a part-time supervisor as opposed to using that position as a stepping stone inside or outside of the company you are missing the point of becoming one. If you become a supervisor you are immediately making more money and learning more things about being in an administrative position within a company which is the primary way that you are ever going to move up to a position above that. You also are around to learn more about the operations of the company. I do feel like people are brainwashed to believe that driving is the only way to be successful in the company, but it is also a very taxing job and I think people would be wise to recognize that if they push themselves they can serve alternative purposes and make themselves appear more valuable in the long run. But the worse con is that if you work mornings, you work approximately 4am-9am most of the year and around Christmas start time is even earlier generally. The reason this is such a bad thing is that when you realize what I realized (that the pay is not that stellar when you are only working 20 hours a week) that you are going to need another job, your only options are part time jobs, retail/food service, and that every job that will pay over 12 dollars an hour is going to be second shift and you will have to split your sleep schedule 4 hours before UPS and 4 hours before your other job. Then when it comes around Christmas time, you are likely unable to hold both jobs at the same time because you simply wont get any sleep between UPS and your second job when you are starting at 1 am.

review_title: Overall cool place to work. Technology driven. Profit driven; sometimes above employee consideration.
job_title: Account Executive in San Francisco, CA
pros: UPS is recognized globally so the brand speaks a great deal for itself as it relates to sales. Many of the people are genuine and customer focused.
cons: Like many things, strengths can be seen as weaknesses and sometimes the preconceptions and/or past history with the brand can negatively impact sales and/or relationship building. Numbers driven! Not apt to change.

pros: Very organized place to work. You always know what your tasks are and what you need to accomplish. The goals are aggressive but once you get the swing of things you know how to approach your day. Management can be hit or miss, depending on the team you land on...fortunately my manager is great to work with, however I know a couple of others I'd probably leave before I worked for them.
cons: Physical work and aggressive goals.

review_title: Wow things have really changed in the past couple of years
pros: Only good thing I can say about this place at this point is maybe the benefits .
cons: Its like waking up every morning to a bad dream. The Stafford management team  has no idea what they are doing, there is no communication between them, its always disorganized and  no respect for their employees, they don't even have respect for each other... Very bad situation....

job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: A challenging and highly competitive work environment that forces you to think outside of the box to solve problems. If you're a hard worker this compnay is for you. When I say hard worker I mean it. If you don't have some blue collar blood in you then you won't make in this environment no matter what side of the workforce you're on (management or union). UPS offers good pay and benefits, the opportunity to advance to higher positions within the company to create a fulfilling career, and you can't beat the job security. If you reach fulltime status in this company and can pull your weight you'll have a good secure job for the rest of your life.
cons: You'll work more hours then you ever have anywhere else and those hours won't be spent at a desk. The environment can be hectic as the entire operation obviously runs to meet strict deadlines and operational goals need to be met daily. Some people find the high pressure too stressful. That's all up to the individual and it comes down to what your made of. Biggest con is that even though there is opportunity to advance it takes forever to do so. Way to long to get full time status within the compnay and upper management have a habit of leaving promotional candidates floating in purgatory for months and sometime years before they finally promote.

pros: UPS is a great company to work for if you are willing to work hard and be self-motivated. Advancing in the company is up to the individual. Seniority is king around here, but work ethic is queen.
cons: It takes a little while to get past the seasonal, temporary BS but once you're in, you're in. Also, long hours do happen. Packages have to be delivered, even on most holidays, in any weather. No days off.

pros:
Free full health benefits for the family
Competitive wages
And you're off the clock in the early morning so you can have two jobs!
cons:
Management talks down to everyone.
Leads from a standpoint of threats and intimidation. There's no accountability for 90% of the workers. They preach on creating safe work environment a, yet turn around and cram volume out creating just the opposite . Also, what kind of employer can never get your working hours right? I'm consistently 1.5 to 2 hrs short on my paychecks.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Nice Weekly paycheck. Work Monday - Friday. Must be on times and have very good attendance. Great benefits for employee's who have been there for more than a year. Union will have your on certain conflicts if chosen to join local UPS union. Will gain a tougher/ stronger toned upper and lower body after getting past the first few months of getting used to the heavy lifting. Most supervisors are awesome people all around. Basic knowledge and easy work if you follow directions about job. Seniority based company, eventually you will have the opportunity to move up to becoming a part time supervisor or a driver after a few years. All around a great company to work for if you would like to pursue a career as a driver from starting from the bottom of the totem pole, metaphorically speaking.
cons: Knees, elbows, and back will take a bad toll on the body from the continuous physical labor. Always sore even if you lift and lower boxes correctly. Not a job for the weak physical bodied or for the wining and complaining mentality type of people (get the job done correctly and go home/ go to your daytime job). If you miss load a package on the wrong truck consistently, you will get badgered by it and may have further disciplinary action held on you. If attendance or calling out sick without doctors note consistently, disciplinary action will be held against you. sleep deprived if not getting enough rest once holiday time comes around, while working double the amount of hours. Possibility to not getting payed over time when peak holiday comes around. part time and full time supervisors will get under your skin if you let it happen or have a short fuse and cant control your anger. make sure to check in with Human Resources about seniority date about signing a seniority bid list for going to drivers school if pursuing a further career becoming a full time driver. If not, then you might get skipped and will have to go to the union rep to ask to sing a grievance paper against the other coworker who had a seniority date underneath yours that went to a higher position before you.

pros: Pay isn't the greatest but the endless possibilities of moving up in the company will keep you there! Most of there promotions come from within the company! Free insurance after a year as a part time employee. Fast paced work that will really get you into shape!
cons: The work is very fast paced and it's a lot of lifting and always pushing you to go faster. The pay doesn't equal the work.

pros: Nonstop physical labor 4-6hrs per day.  Full benefits for a part-time job after one year of employment.  Internal promotion via bid sheets and exams to learn new skills, which translates into raises, eventually.
cons: No "cons" per se, other than no amount of training can prepare one for the reality of the job.  There is no easy way around this job other than doing the job 100%.  What they do not tell you in training is that even though you are assigned to a belt, you will be told, not asked, to assist other belts on an as-needed basis.  It *will* initially come as a shock after working your assigned shift, sweating your butt off, making sure your trailers are clean, walls well-built, irregulars (tires, farm equipment, packages 70lbs+, etc.) stowed away, your supervisor will tell you to report to another belt to help "clean" their trailers (read: do another supervisor/loader's job for them).  This usually happens at the end of day, and is more often than not a thankless task.  One can usually see this coming by the volume of radio squawk throughout the day from other supervisors on the floor:  "PD-X needs help!  PD-Y is getting buried!  PD-Z only has two loaders!"  Even if your PD is shipshape, you are expected to help others as needed.  As long as one focuses on the work itself and ignores what folks around them may or may not be doing, which includes young, misinformed union folks who invariably give the union a bad name (working the bare minimum, threatening supervisors with petty grievances, spreading toxic b.s., etc.- avoid those folks) you'll be ok.  Just do the job.

pros: The people are wonderful, for the most. Of course, there will always be jerks wherever you go. But overall, UPS hires good people that know how to "adult" in tough situations. Old school manners prevail, with men holding doors and waiting for women to enter and exit elevators first - sometimes to comical effect if the woman in question is not used to such gentlemanly behavior (me). Beautiful campus, decent cafeteria, steady and dependable organization.
cons: Dependability sometimes breeds complacency, so long term employees tend to coast in their jobs. The old-timers someone just hold on until retirement (at 55 if you have been an employee for 25+ years!) New employees should not expect that kind of retirement. Contractors do a LOT of work for UPS - but of course - you can be let go at any moment (a downside of contractor life). For the most part, contractors treated fairly, although there is the typical "smoke and mirrors" / red badge crap that still goes on (honestly no different than other contract positions I've had). Also, like many companies-UPS is extremely focused on attracting millennials-often at the expense of neglecting older employees. This is definitely creating some resentments in the troops.

pros: Good pay, over all friendly staff and if you work hard and show a high level of consideration and commitment for your work then the management are pretty easy going.
cons: Safety standards not great.  Outdated technology. Badly organised in some areas.  Equipment broken and in serious need of repair/replacement making the job much harder than it needs to be as well as dangerous.

job_title: Package Handler and Supervisor in Spokane, WA
pros: Not a whole lot. The medical benefits you get are nice, but you have to be with the employer for a year or become a supervisor.
cons: Extremely poor management and all around poor business model. If you want to work for someone who cares about you, don't look here. Willing to sacrifice employee safety and health to make a quick buck. Do the bare minimum of everything and have awful facilities in order to maximize profits.

review_title: UPS is like a little family
pros: Good company to work for, great to start up in as a first or second job. Space for growth within the company. Great experience. Many departments to change around to. Tools for self development available within.
cons: Depending on departments the work load can be heavy. Different countries should work together as a team, getting assistance or information from another department is a challenging at times.

pros: For the most part felt UPS was efficient, organized considering all that was happening at once.  Friendly co-workers.  Good pay.
cons: Loud machinery which sometimes hard to hear instruction or direction.  Equipment such as scanners malfunctioned often so you were left to learn on your own.

job_title: Industrial Engineering Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros: Great management and learning opportunities for a young engineer.  A lot of responsibility is given with the expectation of independent productivity
cons: Company attitude as a whole is negative with a lot of brow beating and stress / anxiety style management.  Everything is a stretch goal resulting in very few "wins".  Company is cheap and does not pay well for a long term engineering career (supervisor salary is competitive at first but raises will not keep up with market value) .  This is a spring board job due to the solid company name and diverse job experience.

review_title: Only one reason to work here
pros: Besides military benefits, no company matches UPS's overall benefits. IS always hire and looking for people.  Benefits does not come out of your check.
cons: No training what so ever, anyone can be a supervisor, even if no supervisor training. Only reason most people stay 1 years + because of the taste of what UPS benefits offers. 3-5 hours a day. Will make it difficult for an employee  to transfer to another hub.

review_title: Unless planning long term employment not worth it
pros:
-Good pay for part time
-weekly paycheck 
-pretty light requirements on the intelligence side of things I.e. really simple job
-don't have to interact with people other than co workers for job related tasks
-I don't use them but I hear the insurance is great
cons:
-Hard work
-No regard for employees time or thoughts by management
-Its a fulltime job disguised as a part time job (honestly got this job for some side money for college there are definitely better options)
-Seniority and established hierarchy can get really annoying.
-Potentially stressful for those easily stressed

pros:
-The benefits are outstanding for part time work
-The job security of union representation
-Seniority based advancement slow but inevitable
cons:
-You will sweat.  This isn't really a big con to me, but it is to a lot of people.
-Union protection means that some truly useless people manage to cling to employment
-Management often don't have a good grasp of what's going on in any given area, open to very limited input from labor.

review_title: how to get around the union?
pros:
great pay,and benefits and strong union to protect jobs. promotes from with in the company.

 best way to get around the union is to document everything on every employee and just say they are not fallowing methods and make sure that you review with the employess daily and continue to be on them to get the production levels that the company demands.
cons: coporate management getting to involved in operations. union getting to involve, union memebers work slower losing the company money. also people dont take pride in their work unless they are management.

pros: The pay at UPS is nothing wow worthy, but that's not the reason most people are there. It's the benefits that keep people around. After 6 months of working, you get free health. There's also a 401k plan that's available from the very first day.
cons: The union. After union dues and the initiation fee, what is left of your paycheck is enough for gas. On average you work 12-15 hours a week and it's just not enough. People often complain about being underpaid and overworked. To be honest, few people are truly over working themselves. Those people adore the union.

review_title: UPS a horrible place to work
job_title: Industrial Engineering Supervisor in Hartford, CT
pros:
pension plan (if it still around when you retire)
good medical benefits
cons: long hours, abusive management and environment, work every holiday (forget about spending any time with family on holidays), have to book vacation a year ahead and booked in seniority order, off hour shifts, very poor merit increases, compensation becomes uncompetitive after only a few years in the job, management is uneducated and an "old boys" network.

review_title: The work is hard, the hours are horrable, other than that, not bad
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Portland, OR
pros: I came to work for UPS because of the tuition assistance and the benifits.  It has also been very stable compared to other companies.
cons: There are certain things that you have to give up to work at UPS.  Everything is part time based work.  To go full time, there is a considerable wait.  The hours are based on sort coverage.  Chances are, you will be giving up your nights.  Evan if you work day sort, you will still be working Sun- thurs

review_title: Very tough environment- dog eat dog every man for themselves within every department.
pros: Good place to work for employees that lack a formalized education. Formal education not important.You can have an MBA from Harvard and still be overlooked for promotion over a truck driver. Most of management lack college degrees. Equal opportunity employer in that respect.
cons: No family life;  long hours;  subjective promotional process and not based on merit or ability. If you come in early, stay late and be kind to the right people irregardless of your ability, you will go very far in this organization.

review_title: Small pay increases, no OT, too much work, bad attitudes within management
pros:
Decent health care benefits, but not as good as it was a several years ago.
Education, if you are a union employee.  A part time union employee can get a Masters, a non-union employee has to be a supervisor or higher to tuition re-imbursement for a Masters.
cons:
Constant consolidation is reducing the number of management positions available.
Over the last five years, the salary increases have been around 2%.
Promotions are based on how well you kiss up to management.
Workload is constantly increasing with no overtime allowed.  With all of the consolidation and reduction in staff, the work has to be dumped on someone.
Management has a "do as I say and not as I do" attitude.
Extreme micro-management, if you are the independent type, your independence will be squashed.

pros: They gave good training, and although the work itself was hard, the work load was somewhat do-able. Also, after a year of working at UPS, you do get benefits.
cons: The downside is that the batteries in the scanner kept on dying, which meant that I had to keep on going back to get another battery. This resulted in the boxes piling up big time!

pros: Financially strong company with good salary and benefits.  Strong potential for advancement in all non-union and management jobs.  Union salary and benefit package is highest in industry.  Company is well respected in it's field and the largest delivery company in the world.
cons: A conservative company with rules and regulations that have to be followed.  The Company expects a lot from its employees but are well compensated for that work.

pros:
Our Legacy, Our People, Our Promise....
* Excellent Benefits (Expecially for the unionized workforce, More than Great Benefits, not quite as Excellent, for the management team
* Job Security
*Safety Focus (Although we occasionally forget that this is more than a number, we are none the less committed)
cons: Currently missing the much needed focus on our shared Legacy; We need Jim Casey to make the difficult decison...Profit or Culture? (Spoiler Alert: Culture is, and always will be,  eduring!)

review_title: Rigid, overly competitive business culture where it's all about efficiency andthe needs of employees don't really count.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: The salary is very good.
cons:
There is a facade of niceness but there was a lack of team spirit. Emphasis in every once-monthly evaluation was on your mistakes and what you had done "wrong" in the past month. No mention was made of positive points.
Business procedures are rigid, with at least 3 hard copies having to be made (by the customer representative) of every corrected invoices over a certain amount for rechecking by the different levels of management.

review_title: Stability is a plus, but even that is fleeting now.
pros: Stability, few layoffs, compensation is ok
cons: A company that takes advantage of it's workforce especially in a hard economy.  Poor work/life balance.  Reduced staff with extreme amounts of work.  Staff is stressed to the point of having ambulances at the office with regularity.  In lieu of layoffs, the management will harass you into retirement or quitting.

review_title: Great company with poor lower level management
pros:
Great employee benefits including medical, dental, and vision. 
Culture of promotion from within the organization to fill jobs.
cons:
Poor training of leadership, which leads to poor operational environment.
Even though it is a great company, your experience with it will depends 100% on the managers in direct control of the operation, which more times than not is poor.

pros: Very good salary pay and all of the workers were nice. Hiring manager was easy to get along with.
cons: Long hours on the job. I worked from 10 AM till 8 PM some nights and it also during the winter time. The work was hard as you are lifting boxes all day but I was prepared for it, because the its in the job description.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Job stability, opportunities for lateral and upward mobility, ability to purchase company shares of stock, no work during weekends.
cons: High stress, micro-management, difficult/ high sales goals, very conservative and strict corporate culture.

pros: A great experience learning the ins and outs of a fortune 500 company. The job was physically taxing and loved every minute of it.
cons: Don't have any bad things to say about my experience. Only that to get a driving route, you must work for $10 an hour in the warehouse with no time frame when you might get a route. 2 years, maybe 5. They don't know. That is why the drivers stay so long.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: It is a job. Easy to get to part time supervision. They will abuse you.  Tuition reimbursement.
cons: The culture has changed so much in the past 10 years. The management is watered down, and the only thing that matters is the bottom line and production. No matter how unsafe it is, or how many damages occur, the faster you go the better they respect you. There is no more quality. Employees hide behind the union, and managers are soft. No one gets fired anymore. Take from management and give to union workers all the time. Management Benefits are abysmal compared to the union workers. No bonuses anymore. Just work and leave.

review_title: Standards set by coked out managers in the 80s.
job_title: Acting Full-Time Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
You have the entire day, free to do what you want if you work the sunrise (morning shift).
Benefits for all employees not hired as holiday only.
cons:
Complete and utter abuse if you are a seasonal holiday hire.
Stockholm Syndrome affects 95% of those that stick around more than a year and you become blind that the rest of the world has surpassed what you consider "great pay".
Only one path of advancement. If you are even granted it -- they will consider you dead if you turn them down to pursue a different internal career path. Basically, never say no. Even if it affects your health or personal life.

review_title: UPS, a good place to work
pros: Pay was decent, people were awesome, job was enjoyable and challenging, benefits were ok.
cons: Management was sometimes shady, work to home life balance was not even like UPS likes to boast about.  Promoting from within happens, but you must be the right demographic that the company needs (black, female, etc) at the time to keep diversity standard or you don't get promoted.  Some folks are passed up for promotion even if they are the most qualified candidate.

pros: Seems like some people do stay there for years. They are offering $200 bonus per week as long as you make it on time but after taxes taken off it is only $100 more (still somewhat helpful)
cons: Some supervisors don't know what they are doing.  A lot of new employees.  Hours changed constantly.  Starting times are always different and ending times changed three times and I was only there for 1 week (+the 1 week training - total of 2 weeks)

pros: Get hired right away.
cons: Driver Helpers are used by Drivers to maximize their route.   Drivers are salaried and you the Driver Helper are paid by the hour, so  they want to drive you like an animal to do as much work as possible.  On some rigorous routes they may have both a morning and afternoon Driver Helper just to maximize productivity.  But this means you're worn out and get fewer hours because you're sharing the day with someone else.    Regularly scheduled Package Center employees often get Saturday routes (if they want the hours) over seasonal Driver Helpers.

job_title: Head Basketball Coach in Williston, FL
pros: UPS is a great Company with great benefits. Its a demanding job and has help me build my mental toughness. I'm also the Head Basketball Coach at Williston Middle High School. Its really great because i not only get to coach basketball but i get to mentor young men.
cons: The only cons of UPS is getting up at 3 am in morning to go to work. But when I get there I'm ready to go.  Being Head Basketball Coach and working at UPS is draining at times get home from games late and getting up at 3 am is really tough.

pros: The benefits package is second to none if you are Union.  If your management, forget about it.
cons: UPS Airlines is run by lying jealous and petty management.  They hate that they are not pilots or mechanics and take it out on both groups whenever possible.  It's always a war environment at work.  Us against them mentality.  The labor management department are scum who use dishonesty to fire people with no care about the truth or the persons family or future.  It's no wonder that there have been cases of workplace violence seemingly every year throughout the UPS network.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Commerce City, CO
pros: Steady work, regular pay raises.  Good pay for the work.  When I needed more hours they got as close to full time as possible
cons: No full time positions unless you are management or drive.  Management often becomes management by attrition , or better stated, they were there the longest.  The positions aren’t always wanted.

pros:
Driver helper is an easy and fun way to get some part-time work and extra money. 

Every driver I worked with was nice, helpful, and patient.  Just follow their lead and instructions and you can't go wrong.  Make sure you hustle.

Job description is literally taking packages from the truck to a house or office, about as simple as it gets.  Customer interaction is generally pretty easygoing.  Everybody likes the UPS guy, especially around the holidays.  The drivers will teach you how to use the signature board which is very easy to use once you get it down.  It took me about two days to master.  Also, paid orientation!

Ideally you'd like to eventually be assigned to the same route/driver just for consistency's sake.  Otherwise you'll be going to different places and different times all the time.  At first I was bouncing around different routes but eventually got on the same route for the last couple weeks before Christmas, which was good because it was hours you could count on plus it was more comforting getting used to the route and generally knowing what to expect.

Can be physically demanding, but comes with the side effect of getting a good workout during the day.

It's an easy job and I'd say better than working at the mall during the Christmas season.  I'd definitely do it again.
cons:
Probably the biggest downside is dealing with the winter weather element.  Being December, it will more than likely be cold, windy, snowy, etc.  One day we had to deliver after an ice storm hit that morning and nearly got the truck stuck.  Every porch and step was covered with ice.  Got to be careful!

As you'd expect it's hourly pay, and work will only come as demand allows for, so the opportunity to make a ton of money is somewhat limited.  Some routes may only last for three or four hours, some maybe six to eight, it depends on the route and the volume.  I worked a couple eight to nine hour days the week of Christmas.  If you are good at the job and a driver puts in a good word, the opportunity to work every day should be there, but there's no guarantee.  Also, sometimes they will try to limit your hours if you're working a lot in a particular week, which is understandable on one hand but also kind of silly.  

No lunch break, so bring food.  Generally there's not too much time to snack anyway on the route.  I learned to eat a lot before work which would help, especially after a shift ending at 8 pm or so.

- Rigid management incapable of thinking outside of the box.
- Tons of inefficiency and redundancy that no one does anything about.

- Arrogant management whose egos are 10x the size of their brains or actual ability.

review_title: Very hard work, driven like a slave, but good management and pay was not too bad.
pros:
As part-time preloader, the pay wasn't too bad. $8.5 per hour plus I think it was a 50cent to $1 raise in the first 3-6 months, and then another later on. That plus the Teamster contract, the pay shouldn't be too bad now.

First 5.5 hours of work in a day  is normal pay, then it goes to overtime, and then at 11 hours it goes to double. During peakseason, there were no days where I didn't work at least 9-10 hours, so at the starting pay of 8.5 (maybe 9.5 now) the pay was pretty good. :) Definitely try to start with a peakseason (November through Feb) as they are almost always accepting people and if you prove yourself well throughout those months, they WILL hire you back. I worked my butt off and I knew I was getting hired at the end of the season within the first few weeks. If you can't find any UPS ads for help, GO TO THE CENTER CLOSEST TO YOU and ask for an application. Tell them you want to work for them. Dress decently (not too well, you're not going to be working a suit and tie job lol) and present yourself nicely.

You'll get in shape.
cons:
The work is very fast paced so get ready. You can do it if you have a normal sense of urgency though. :)

It may be hard to get hours during the regular season unless you work at a super large center. I worked a decently sized center and we only got about 25-30 hours in a week after peak season of about 50+.

review_title: UPS - A Safe Place to Work, but Don't Think that Brown Can Do Much for your Advancement
pros: The best reason to work for UPS in a management capacity is security.  UPS, in my knowledge, has never laid any of its management team off.  There have been offers of early retirement, but not any layoffs.  An other reason is the benifits and pay are pretty good - not the best, but certainly not the worst.
cons: There is no real opportunity for advancement... And when there is, it does not seem to be based on performance.  First, many of the upper management group are marking time until they reach age 55 and can get their full retirement benefits.  This makes total sense when you realize that there is a huge difference in the monthly pension payment before and after one turns 55.  In my opinion, this causes a few problems.  First, there are very few opening in the upper management.  I know of many upper managers who, as it was widely known, were given "special" assignments for their last year or two that equated to executive day-care.  Secondly, because these openings are few and far between, no one wants to "rock the boat", so to speak, and endanger their slim chance for advancement.  No one will give any type of feedback that could be construed as negative.  If you get one strike, you are out!  When I had serious concerns with what were deemed important initiatives, I personally have been told to keep those concerns to myself because I might offend someone.  Or worse, I might be asked to take over that project!  UPS used to pride itself by having managers that were "constructively dissatisfied" and worked to make things better.  Now it seems if you utter one word of criticism, you are branded a malcontent.  The last downside to working at UPS are the unions.  Their personal healthcare costs are never increased while every year the management finds itself responsible for more and more of their own healthcare costs.  And every 5 years when their contract is up for renewal, you find yourself holding your breath that the union does not walk out again and significantly drop the stock price because a lot of your bonuses are tied up in company stock.  Because of these and other issues, I have seen talented person after talented person who I could lead the company leave because of limited advancement.

review_title: UPS - A great place to work if you are single
pros: The benefits that are offered if you can make it through the probationary period are the primary reason most people come to work for UPS. As management there is also the bonus incentives given each year based on company performance and meeting shareholder and internal expectations. We have offices in over 100 countries and once in management there is a good deal of flexibility for transfer for school reasons or if a spouse gets relocated. The pride that UPSER's have for not only the company but for the customers is one that is very unique and not found in many other fortune 500 companies. There is a great deal of focus and importance put on the customer and working together to achieve their goals is something that often times requires the work of many different people and/or departments to accomplish. There are very few other companies or organizations that can offer such a wide array of departments and work experience. The amount of different job functions and departments within the company can provide job potential for someone with an engineering degree, a business degree, a computer degree, a marketing degree, etc... so there is a lot of opportunity for growth within the company. With all the various departments there is a great deal of opportunity for movement to gain cross-fucntional training to really learn how each department impacts the flow of packages and data within the network. One thing that UPS is very good at is moving people around to get experience in various functions of the day to day business so they get the big picture.
cons: The hours required to accomplish everything that is typically expected of a full time supervisor are greater then many other full time salary supervisors in other companies. Based on the department or operation you are working in the average day can be from 10 or 12 hours to 14 to 16 hours depending on the projects being implemented or the time of year. The holidays are not fun for anyone who works in management at UPS in the day to day operational functions or planning functions. There is no such thing as family time after the week of Thanksgiving until after the New Years Day holiday and there is little to no flexibility for time off during this period as well. Many days during the Christmas holiday season require many full time management to work 16 to 18 hour days if not longer on some occasions leaving no time for family activities since you are usually too tired to move when you return home. Most of the management I work with have grown to hate the holiday season as much as I have in the past 3 years of working these kinds of hours which often times include Saturdays and sometimes Sundays. If it weren't for the ability to do almost all my Christmas shopping online I wouldn't probably be able to find the time to actually go to the mall and shop during the month of December. Another downside is the union aspect and how much control they have. It is very disheartening when management is able to build cases against hourly union employees to get them terminated just to have the union get them their job back time and time again. Not all employees that are members of the union abuse the system but there are still a lot that do and it makes if very difficult to hold employees accountable when you can't rightfully terminate them and make it stick. This frustrates young management when they see this and gives off the impression that management has no power or authority to terminate problem employees. Finally the last downside is the lack of notice when a move or change is made. Often times when a management change is made it is kept very secret and typically not told to the affected employee(s) until a day or two before. This can cause a lot of strain on peoples family lives at home where their spouse or significant other is affected by the change in positions which often times involves changes in the hours or time of day.
