review_title: A take from a part-time management employee's perspective of UPS Package Handling Operation
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Miami, FL
pros:
UPS gives its part time management employees an array of benefits. That's not too common for part time employees nowadays. You will receive medical, dental and vision benefits. You initially receive  weeks of vacation a year and a third week after 5 years of service. Vacation time continues to grow at some scale thereafter. A 401(k) is also provided with employer matching that fluctuates often and not for the better most of the time.

The pay is also pretty competitive given the job you'll be doing, but you might question that from time to time. (Read cons)
cons:
UPS Operation (the operation that physically moves their parcels from within UPS hubs and onto other hubs) is anything but a professional environment. You'll be working with unionized employees and that can make your job substantially hard than it should be. The employees have a substantial amount of rights that protect them from the kind of discipline that someone else would receive at another job. 

Employees come late or miss work altogether whenever they please and that's the norm. This defies conventional wisdom. Conventional wisdom says that if you don't come to work for a week without saying a word about, you get fired. That's not the case at UPS thanks to the Teamsters union. When they're present they have the option of working at whichever pace they feel fit to work at and this is often a subjective measure that always works in the package handler's favor. This makes it extremely hard for management personnel like myself to meet the goals that're set up by the Industrial Engineering Department.

In the end you find yourself in a very hostile environment where we pay some of our package handler's $22/hr to make our operation worse and that can be the worst feeling ever when you're part of management and you would want nothing more than to see operation reach the goals it's supposed to reach. Instead you find yourself conforming constantly to situations you should not have to conform to... and that's the norm.

review_title: A great place for entry-level warehousing, and can be a great career opportuinity if you stick with it.
pros:
During the busy holiday season they hire a lot of seasonal workers, even those who have no experience so it's a great way to start a resume. The work itself felt rewarding although it was hard, but it's essentially being paid to work out if you are on the floor loading or unloading. I worked with some great people and it was a decent part-time job for a while. If you stay there long enough to be in the union any work after five hours in a day is overtime. You can make bank during the Christmas season, handing packages and doing driver helper. The supervisor's and management was probably the best I've worked with as they are very hands on and detail-oriented. 

Is a great workout as well, and once you've been there a while it can be hard to get fired or quit as you can get yearly raises.
cons: The hours are very early, usually was around 4:00 am most days, and for most of the year after peak you'd be lucky to get three hours a day. It makes it tough to also work another full time job because you can get exhausted pretty easily coming from it. And in order to get free health coverage you have to work there a year. They could also improve their sorting systems and methods of labeling. And since it's union based becoming a full time driver takes years, I know some people who've been there over five years and are still waiting to drive even during peak season. The work itself can also be overwhelming at times and you can get yelled at for not keeping up to their liking at times.

review_title: Easy Interview Process--Be ready to run
pros: This seasonal job is exactly that--helping UPS drivers during their busiest time of the year. The work is pretty basic but the intensity is determined by your level of interest in doing more for the driver (such as working the devices used by drivers to track packages), number of hours worked, and neighborhoods served. Depending on the driver, the job should be very predictable, with a usual late start for the helper (drivers have to get to the warehouse earlier to get their delivered for the day and then meet you in their delivery area...so 9:45-11:00 am start time was normal). I lost 10 lbs. in 3 weeks--that's how much I was moving to get packages delivered to homes.
cons: It seems the seasonal peek time results in some interesting changes in the drivers. First, many veteran drivers take vacation, so new and less experienced drivers take over. This doesn't make it a bad experience, but sometimes they get new neighborhoods they themselves don't know well  yet, so routes can take longer. Second, days can get super long, as in, making deliveries as late as after 9:00 pm, but how long you work as a seasonal helper is up to you. Last, I felt training for this position was too short. We could have spent some time on an actual truck to practice quick safety tips, such as how to exit the truck or how to organize boxes. UPS relies on the drivers to do a lot of on the job training/management for the seasonal helpers. They seem to be disappointed that we come to them with incomplete information and training.

review_title: Easy Interview Process--Be ready to run
pros: This seasonal job is exactly that--helping UPS drivers during their busiest time of the year. The work is pretty basic but the intensity is determined by your level of interest in doing more for the driver (such as working the devices used by drivers to track packages), number of hours worked, and neighborhoods served. Depending on the driver, the job should be very predictable, with a usual late start for the helper (drivers have to get to the warehouse earlier to get their delivered for the day and then meet you in their delivery area...so 9:45-11:00 am start time was normal). I lost 10 lbs. in 3 weeks--that's how much I was moving to get packages delivered to homes.
cons: It seems the seasonal peek time results in some interesting changes in the drivers. First, many veteran drivers take vacation, so new and less experienced drivers take over. This doesn't make it a bad experience, but sometimes they get new neighborhoods they themselves don't know well  yet, so routes can take longer. Second, days can get super long, as in, making deliveries as late as after 9:00 pm, but how long you work as a seasonal helper is up to you. Last, I felt training for this position was too short. We could have spent some time on an actual truck to practice quick safety tips, such as how to exit the truck or how to organize boxes. UPS relies on the drivers to do a lot of on the job training/management for the seasonal helpers. They seem to be disappointed that we come to them with incomplete information and training.

review_title: Barbaric and personally degarding workplace for Supervisors
pros: They pay relatively well, but not when you work out your hourly rate and you're on salary.  Some days I made less than $15 an hour while the drivers I supervise made $35 plus overtime.
cons: 6 day work week.  11 to 15+ hour days.  Confrontational management style where it's always who do we blame.  No room for personal growth.  You will do bargaining unit work everyday you work there.  High blood pressure, stress, pressure, and no positive feedback for a job well done.  Working here will ruin your marriage.

pros:
I absolutely love working at UPS, anyone young looking for a job they should definitely look into working at UPS! there is a lot of pros/cons working for this company, but what company will you work for and advance your position and get GREAT benefits?! 
Hourly employee- union
Supervisor/Management- non union
cons:
This company lets you get away with a lot, the union stands behind you if you are an hourly employee, sometimes so much that people get away with crap they shouldn’t! 
Oh what? You don’t have to call in if you don’t want to go to work? Oh wait, you mean to tell me you don’t have to go to work for weeks and not get in trouble? Well, you might get written up but it’s takes A LOT to get fired!
They want you to work safe, but yet they want you to work as fast as possible (which I’ve done and got hurt 2 times) 
Sometimes I feel like I’m working in a sweatshop, LOW pay (you mean to tell me that In-n-out burger employees gets paid more than me?) 
You will get bruises in places you didn’t know existed, part time employees get about 3 1/2-4 hours unless it’s extremely busy! I wish they paid more that’s for sure, even supervisors I feel they don’t get paid for what they have to put up with.
1 thing I can’t stand is if you are working past the 3:45 hours most of the time they will not pay you for a break, you actually have to remind them to either give you a break or add time to your check. 
It’s so easy to walk away from your job and just walk around the warehouse and no one will know for hours, you can literally just go around and talk to people and supervisors and no one will say anything.

pros: Good company to work for and start a career if you can deal with being PT for at least 4-5 years if you are lucky.Once you do your minimum time the benefits are good and better then most for part time work. Management is helpful depending on the section and what hub you are at. Pretty flexible with what shift you work and as long as you come in and do the job to the best of your ability you will be fine. Peak season you can pick up decent hours and normally get overtime.
cons: I had some personal flaws at the hub that i worked at in California. Lot of empty promises on promotions and such. Recommend keeping a small notebook in a pocket to write down things you see throughout the shift. IE: management touching packages and working. They are not allowed to because it takes time away from the union worker. Expect to be at the bottom of the pole for a long time until you put your dues in. If you were say hired and placed in "load side" worked that side for 2 years, then switched to "small sort" in the same building you will lose your seniority in that new section. There is "hub/building seniority  and "section" seniority. You will feel like you are stuck in "PT" for ever. Some people are PT for 5-9 years before they can move up to either start cover driving or pick up a FT position somewhere in the Hub. Most definitely recommend having a FT or at least another PT job on the side. Look forward to maybe if you are lucky 3 hours max per day unless its "Peak" season.

review_title: Unfulfilling, higher-ups impossible to get in contact

I worked 25 hours the first week, then it was less than that every week after. I would only be able to work for 4-6 hours per shift, and they determined that the day of. I had to call in every day and have an open availability to be able to make that $150 bonus. I wasn’t getting enough hours so I’d pick up other work, and then, of course, they would need me that day so I never got the extra $150.

Extremely difficult to contact higher-ups- I had never received my compensation for the five hours of training, in addition to a week towards the end of Dec. I tried contacting HR, but you have to just send an email. They would never get back to me. When I’d call, I’d be transferred 3-4 times, on hold, and end up talking to someone who said they’d have to call back. They never did. Finally, in probably June or July, they sent me a letter saying that they noticed I hadn’t cashed a check for $49 and that I needed to fill out a form and they would send the check to me. I filled it out and wrote a letter and additional email reminding them about the training hours. They said it could take 3-4 weeks to actually get it. review_title: Only two good jobs at UPS: Driver and CEO, and I'm not sure about the former.
job_title: Package Dispatch Supervisor in Albany, NY
pros: UPS is a stable long term company with a rock solid business model. UPS has a long history of rolling with the punches, and while DHL is going out of business in the US, UPS has not layed-off a single employee, and likely won't have to. The compensation for management employees is decent, and the compensation for full time union employees is unmatched. UPS is evolving at a remarkable pace for an old growth company, and there are many opportunities for people with good problem solving skills and an ability to find unique solutions to complex logistical problems. Boredom is not a problem anyone will every face at UPS.
cons: Incredible stress and long hours are the norm at UPS. We coined the phrase: Part time means full time and full time means all the time. Christmas used to be a four letter word at UPS, but now we work 12-14 hour days all year round, sometimes 6 days a week. Senior management has lost their minds since the IPO back in the late 90's. We spend so much time worrying about the pennies that we are missing mountains of money driving by the front door. Everyone is so concerned with making their particular indexes, that no one is asking: "is this right for the business". The union employees keep getting better and better contracts, meanwhile the company makes their costs by continually increasing the workload on the supervisors, and cutting the benefits and pensions. UPS used to make supervisors and managers quite well off at retirement, now I doubt there will *be* a pension when I retire. As for medical, the Teamsters have health benefits that are as good as government health benefits, while the rest of us are left with "option C". If my son weren't covered under my *wifes* health coverage, his 9 day stay in the NICU would have cost me my house and my car. Another supervisor I know was receiving donations to pay for the portions of his Chemo that his health plan wouldn't cover. I leave you with three words to consider: Mandatory unpaid overtime.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: i work as a Part-Time Sup out of the Seattle Hub.  I'd say how long i've worked there, but it would single me out as turn-over for even my level of management is not far off from part-time hourlys.  We are expected to work somewhere in the neighborhood of 25 to 27.5 hours per week.  Anything above that is an hourly calulation based on your monthly salary, it comes out to be straight time if one were paid hourly.  Bonuses were taken away as of this year and spread out as weekly pay.  As a PT sup, we also get tuition assistance.  It comes out to $4k per year which is $1k more than PT hourly.   Promotions are possible and no longer require a 4 year degree within management.
cons: A lot of stress comes with being a manager of UPS.  The union is very unforgiving when it comes to grievences.  Upper management typically has horrible plans for increasing production or decreasing labor.  Upper management rarely seeks advice from hourlys or lower management staff on best practices.  The technology used (aside from bluetooth scanners) is laughable.  I often have to use a 15 year old computer with an even older 3rd party software to complete some of my tasks.  To reboot the program takes half an hour minimum.   it doesn't make sense when I could go to a garage sale and pick up a new(er) computer that would run over 3x as fast for less than the cost of a grievence.

review_title: Initially Great But The Cracks Are Showing
pros: Initially the pay (including gain sharing, christmas bonus, benefits etc.) and the opportunity for advancement - not to mention the tuition reimbursement - greatly exceeded any other part-time job out there.  the camaradarie is unheard of in the modern business world and the family (albeit dysfunctional at times) atmosphere makes it much easier to go into such a high-stress environment.
cons: unfortunately with the economic downturn many of the "selling" points for part-time management positions have been cut (gain sharing, christmas bonus).  part-time sups along with the hourly employees are on the front lines and will be the first to feel the brunt of a tough operating day.  while the union is still protecting it's employees livelyhoods the part-time sups are now being asked to do more with less (this coming from a sup who helped propel a certain shift into the number one slot in the country for overall performance).  the pressure's mounting but the incentives for performing above and beyond your job description are disappearing.  it would be a shame to see a one hundred year plus company lose some of it's greatest assets - it's people - just to save a few dollars even though the company still manages to pull in hundreds of millions (perhaps a few billion) dollars in revenue even during the economic crises.  i'm not naive.  it's a capitolist company in a capitolist society and making money by offering superior service to our customers is the nature of the business.  it would be a shame though to see greed lose many of the people who helped make the company all that money in tough times.  you guys have made it a long time by being a company that holds integrity up high.  if you keep putting the squeeze on the men and women on the front lines you won't just be losing that integrity.

pros:
Overall the experience was positive. The upper management is very conservative and can be a bit rigid at times. The workload can be heavy and exhausting with lots of strategic initiatives and confusing competitions. 

The training process is very thorough and the company does a good job teaching the basics fundamentals of sound business practices. The corporate training schools are educational and interesting while being fun. The company does have a strong team feeling.

The total compensation package was ok. I worked in two different states and experienced the opportunity to transfer within the organization. I was allowed to move states without losing my stock options.
cons:
Working for UPS can kind of resemble working for the military. The company has a rank-and-file management style where you earn your stripes. It does feel like you have to "do your time" before receiving promotions instead of being based on merit.

The work can be monotonous and lacks creativity. I think the company has a lot of potential to improve the workplace by encouraging a little more ingenuity.

Given the exhaustive nature of the work, not that it is overall that complicated, the total compensation package is just ok. The company would do itself a favor by improving the total salary. The benefits were good, no problems there.

During my transfer, I had to pay for the move, which I didn't mind. I moved from an area with a lower cost of living to a higher cost of living. While I did receive some consideration in my base salary, it was nowhere near close to an equivalent relative pay structure. This was a pretty major down-side.

The final decision that it was time to move on when the company went through a reorganization. Essentially, the company downsized managment jobs by one third. While my job in sales was secure, it was clear that there would be significantly fewer opportunities for advancing my career. 

Good job and great career builder, but not worth the 30 year wait for a gold watch and a pension.

pros: UPS is good for the long haul. If you want to stay a very long time this is the place to be. Most employees stay for 10,20, 30 years and retire.
cons: The worklife/balance for the management team is not great. You work long hours and there is no compensation or rewards for putting in the extra effort.

pros: Dedicated partners in the trenches with you. Great friendship and a sense of community with the business and the employees.
cons: Too many too many.... Hours, requests, projects, directions, department requests, initiatives and real work to be able to manage... Far more work to do then time if you do things correct... if you cut corners and work 40 hours a week... someone will get hurt...

review_title: Good workout, Good benefits. Pay suitable for a student/work-life balance.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Atlanta, GA
pros:
The health benefits are very nice when compared to other companies (especially part-time).
Included is health/dental/vision. Have had no problems with the provider of the insurance.

Somewhat flexible hours.

Opportunities for overtime during peak seasons primarily but offered somewhat regularly as well.

Once you obtain seniority, the pay gets better and better (especially for part-time work).

Have had very little issues with my school schedule/work schedule. Supervisors have worked with me on the conflicts.

Good workout and even get a short break during the shift if all things are going well.

Lots of different ways to pursue a different job type once you get your foot in the door.

Once you have time under your belt here, the vacation time/sick days/option days-week are pretty attractive. again, especially for part-time work.

Tuition assistance is available.

Military friendly company (maintain seniority during deployments).
cons:
Although many opportunities exist to move around the company, it is a very slow and diluted process. 

The flow of information and standard operating procedures is atrocious at times. 

People in leadership positions need to be sent to a simple leadership course to help some of them learn how to properly lead a team and address issues. 

Supervisors need to be educated much more than they are on standard operating procedures and filing of paperwork.

It is very difficult to switch shifts, which I found somewhat odd for part-time work. Luckily, I have been fortunate enough to have had little issues with my school/work schedule thus far.

Moving from the area you were hired to another area but doing the same job, still makes you lose your seniority. This seems very unfortunate for someone who wishes to stay with the company yet must relocate. The pay gets pretty good and it does not behoove you to move and lose your pay rate. 

Management of personnel is a little bit sub-par. Again, supervisors seem to have a lack of education in proper personnel/time management skills.

pros: UPS is a desirable employer from my perspective.  They reward hard-working individuals with good pay and great benefits.  Management is flexible with good employees.
cons: UPS is a bare bones, no frills cost effective production where time really is money.  The major downside is that it is so difficult to gain full time permanent employment there.

review_title: Very taxing on your ability to handle stress mentally.
pros: If you take advantage of the learning opportunities and the hands on training, you will more than benefit from the experience. The ability to manage people is a huge resume builder if your just getting started. Learn the SCM skill sets and get proof of your training. Excellent place to learn the ropes. The company is solid so you don't have to worry about getting laid off and the benefits are great. Just don't do it for the pay.
cons: You wont get any understanding from upper management for personal or school issues. I had a close family member pass and wasn't given more than my 3 days off. School, forget about it. If your management you are expected to be there until the job is done. If you can handle that, then you'll be alright. Very little recognition for your efforts and promotions are given to friends rather than people who can get the job done. Lastly if something goes wrong, you will get thrown under the bus. You really have to work hard to cover all your bases and document every attempt to prevent failure. If you plan on going management you need to plan on going up. Don't stay in the lower ranks for very long. 3-4 years tops. Make friends with your management staff no matter how much their expectations are crazy. Bottom line (kiss some butt for a few years)

review_title: Lots of stability with little frills
pros: Stable place to work and benefits package includes a 401k and pension (though the pension may be in the process of phasing out)
cons:
You get a large bonus but half of that money is prorated over 5 years. 

Room for advancement can be limited due to a lack of positions available.  Since I've started at UPS 7 years ago I've seen two early retirement buyouts and two district consolidations all while not one position has been added to my department.  The current objective of upper mgmt is to cut NonOp and reduce overstaffing.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Palatine, IL
pros: Good workout, great insurance, wages automatically increase every 6 months. The longer you're there, the better the job is. Union gives you job security, can pretty much do anything short or stealing and completely stop showing up and you still won't be fired. Health benefits are amazing, only a $10 copayment and free prescriptions to most medicines.
cons: Constantly working; lifting and moving boxes. Could be working as fast as you can but your supervisors will still come up and say you're not moving fast enough. No air conditioning so the building literally becomes a "sweat shop" in the summer months. No matter how long you're there, you'll only get ONE ten minute break, even if you've been working hard for 6 hours. Must join the union and union dues take money out of your already small paycheck. Very dirty, very dusty, you WILL be blowing out big black boogers out your nose at the end of every day. After you've done it for a while, it becomes mindless work, and you can't use any music listening devices or cell phones to keep your mind occupied. Some of your other coworkers might be lazy and you have to pick up their slack. If  you work hard and you're good a what you do, they place you with someone that works hard too, making your job extra hard because you're forced to keep up with the flow. No ones cares about anybody but themselves. Sure you can help the people around you, but unless you think about yourself first, the place will eat you alive. There are multiple entities (union, united way, drive,etc) that would like you to donate even more money out of your already small paycheck.

review_title: Poor career development in Information Systems
job_title: Software Quality Analyst in Paramus, NJ
pros: The only reason I can think of of working for UPS would be the salary , the need for a job.
cons: I worked for UPS for almost 15 years. Studied and graduated from Montclair University, Computer Science. UPS was first company after graduating from college. I did not have the opportunity to put in practice and develop any computer skills. No opportunity to become a programmer, After being transfer to another department, i opted to become a software tester or quality analyst. Management did not have a clue in how to manage QAs, we learned as we go, we had to train ourselves in learning the system, No leadership at all, learning based on digging documentation from different groups or departments since our group test a suite of applications our only resource was to reach to these different groups. Company acquired software for testing like QTP and Blackbox, again at least in my case I was denied the opportunity in getting familiar in using these important tools. After the second year in this department after I self trained then I became 'comfortable' with testing all these applications. When I was transferred again, due to reduction of personnel in this department, (after surviving the 2009 'clean up' (removing of employees that did not meet expectations from management) I had to go through the same, this time even worse, management told me I did not have to learn the old legacy application. Since this was a new project, I did the same learn on my own everything that I could. Self trained in QTP and Loadrunner which was required. However to my surprise, out of the blue, I was told to test the old application which I never bother learning. This cause the first conflict with my manager. After that my reviews went down to a point that apparently my performance was unacceptable and practically I was 'forced' to opt to retire or get fired.

review_title: The hardest physical job in a civilized society
pros: Good pay, Good benefits. Union.
cons: Now trying to cut benefits. Pay has not kept up with inflation. Won't hire porters to clean anymore and hubs are disgustingly dirty. Cheap on heat in winter. Lousy ten minute break and you are suppose to work like a machine the rest of the time.Part timers are constantly being sent home and not given their lousy three hour guarantee. Drivers are constantly being sent out with twelve hour days. They work you literally to death. Even when your body starts feeling it and breaking down they have no  mercy. Have now cut management to a minimum. Have cut their benefits, no more pension for new management, and their raises are ridiculously cheap. The part time sups work harder then the Union employees. There is no opportunity for advancement because there aren't a lot of driving jobs available. And the combo jobs we won from the strike of 97 the company isn't filling like they should. They are splitting these jobs and making you work two  different shifts. How can anyone have a life if they have to drive back and forth twice a day and work four hours each shift. Or sleep in the parking lot because you can't drive all the way home. And to those who say there was a tour before we were hired....Hahahahahaha. There are videos we watched too and they are nothing like reality. Once you are vested in a pension it's not an easy thing to walk away and not collect that pension which would be quite small, until your mid sixties. People here are just telling it like it is for the next guy. I'll bet about eighty percent of the workforce doesn't really like the job they are in. Most new hires don't make it a week. And as far as a workout while getting paid...that's how I looked at it when I was twenty. Then I had two hernia surgeries, and repeated back problems. They expect you to sort or load in excess of 300 packages an hour. A body isn't made for that and it takes tough, tough people to last until retirement in this company. That is why I am proud to say I work there. It says a lot about me and strength.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Bloomington, IN
pros: You get decent health insurance if after you work for a year and join the union. You get plenty of standard perks after you work for a year. You just have to survive.
cons: Warehouse conditions can be extreme. Employee turnover is high, so don't expect to make any friends. The ones who have been around the longest are a miserable lot. This could be due to the few obscure hours you get to work per week and the lack of opportunities in the company. Only a lucky few get promoted by being foolish enough to endure working there for several years.

review_title: Benefits where great, but thats about it.
pros: Benefits where superb compared to any other. Never paid out of pocket for much. Prescription was 5$ or free for generic. Never really got disciplined for lack of attendance. Sometimes. If you are a student they will help with tuition it ain't much but it's something.
cons: Part time proverty. Teamsters brothers and sisters often would hide instead of working. If someone had more seniority they automatically wanted someone else to do the job. Teamsters have fallen apart and have no back bone. It takes 10 years to become full time.

pros: I love getting to meet new people all the time and seeing all the different things that we import as a country.  I also love the challenges of solving the problems of supply chain and getting items to the go old U.S. of A.
cons: Cons are not a lot of room for growth.  Commission structure is almost impossible to understand. And promotions sometimes seem to be based on tenure and not hard work.

pros:
I started out as a part-time package handler. This was a second job, certainly not my primary job. The good points were: 
*literally getting paid to work out for four hours 
*the job kept me extremely busy so my evening flew by
*great free benefits at the time of my hire (used to take effect after 90 days for entire family, now it's a full year just for yourself)
*Teamsters stand behind you (though they do stand behind the full-time employees a little sturdier)
*I made some great friends while there. 
I seriously never had a single problem with supervisors or managers as an hourly. My observation is most hourlies who do have problems with managers are the ones who don't want to do the work.

Then I was hoodwinked into becoming a P/T supervisor. Maybe it is just me, but I seriously can't think of any Pro for this position. I curse the day I finally gave in to the pestering to become a supervisor.
cons:
As an hourly employee (non-supervisor), management can seem to be pretty mean bunch; they will be if you don't do your job.
*The building has no climate control so you burn up in the summer and freeze in the winter if you aren't prepared
*If you were hired after May 2008, you have to work an entire year before you get benefits for yourself, 18 months to get benefits for your family.
*If you're one of the harder workers, supervisors are going to pick you to work late and to do the really difficult jobs; they send the crappy employees home as soon as the sort is finished so as to not put up with them. Unfortunately, I did the same thing to my strong employees once I was a supervisor.

As a P/T Supervisor: 
*You lose those free benefits you had as an hourly employee
*Putting up with hourlies who want to do nothing but start trouble and who don't want to work
*Documenting everything the bad employees do to get them disciplined or terminated and then finding out your manager really doesn't have your back (even though you get screamed by the same manager every day you don't write-up the offending employee)
*You are responsible for not wrapping up in time even though you need at least three more hourlies to do the job and you're trying to handle twice the volume your equipment is designed to handle.

As an FYI, after I began working here I made it a point to NEVER ship anything fragile via UPS.

review_title: Good job; good benefits; Hard work;
pros: Good Benefits (Medical, Vision, Dental, 401-K, Tuition Reimbursement), Flexible schedules to choose from (perfect for students), Yearly raises (about  $1.00/ yr), Opportunities for advancement (You can get promoted from loader/ unloader to Sorter for $1.00 raise after 30 days or a few months, I can't remember exactly) Also, if you're interested in Management/ Business or Logistics/ Communications, etc, you can move up in the company, they promote from within. It can take years to become a full-time driver, and though that position pays well (about $20/ hr) it's HARD WORK and basically a dead-end job, but if you're life aspiration is to be a UPS driver then go for it! I enjoyed being a sorter for 12 years, when I left them I was at $17.50/ hr. Just wasn't enough hours though (20-30 wk); Was great exercise; stayed fit & strong.  Management was awesome; very understanding; were all very cool when I started my "transition" on the job (I'm an FTM trans man) They all knew me as a very butch "lesbian" and most of my supervisors were happy for me and all were respectful when I changed my name & started taking Testosterone/ living as male. HR went out of their way to make accomodations for me (talking to my supervisors about using correct pronouns & allowing me to use the men's RR)
cons: Low starting pay rate (when I started in 2001 it was $8.50/ hr), horrible hours, sometimes as little as 20-25 hours a week, if they're staffed they'll send you home (or you can demand your full 4 hours); takes years to get a full-time position; I worked as a loader & sorter: both extremely strenuous positions; this is hard, physical labor; weaklings need not apply. My biggest complaint is that their insurance policy was "trans-exclusive" meaning, even though I had worked for them for almost twelve years, their insurance policy denied my trans-related surgeries (hysto, mastectomy, phalloplasty) which is why I ended up leaving the company. It's a very conservative company in general & they never seemed to take steps to adopt LGBT inclusive policies. This is a shame considering how many transsexual and LGBT employees they have. I was a seasonal and then full-time driver for a couple of years and it was a nightmare (for me personall) others love it. It's a HEAVY HEAVY WORKLOAD; long hours, back-breaking work; was not fun for me at all. Requires a lot of customer service as opposed to the laid-back, casual atmosphere in the warehouse/ HUB. I never got any bonuses; the environment is not intellectually stimulating at all; very monotonous, robotic/ repetitive work. Hot, sweaty, dusty, dirty; drove my allergies/ skin nuts; broke out in hives; had panic attacks as a result of the beeping scanners and insanity of the whole parcel hub system; ugh.

pros: Working in internationals is a small and separated group from the main operations in a center or Hub.  That separation keeps me able to have independence and not feel micromanaged.
cons: UPS is a center that like many warehouses or industrial operation, has a lot of conflict and scandal.  Managers try to cover up labor issues and laborers have a rigorous job.

review_title: The Memory of a Goldfish and the Foresight of a Mole.
pros:
- Great for the workaholic, singleton, isolationist, or machine man.

- Money - Good for the type of multi drop deliver work of its kind. 

- Occasional Junk or kids party food on the company if you like that sort of thing.

- If you are productive and efficient the management largely ignore you. (Only of course to burden you with more work.)
cons:
- Your life belongs to UPS.

- Constant, unapologetic, psychological pressure to take on more and more and more.

- Jaded robot management who parrot company mantra, military style, but are happy to break all their own rules to ensure both the shop floor and the 'figures' look good for their bosses in turn so as to recoup their bonus related incentives.

- Daily, and periodical condescension programs for the Kindergarten level mind.
Firstly, in the form of repetitive, unnecessary, morning meetings to tell you what happened the day before, which is futile, to offer amateur interpretations of things such as meterology, false management to worker camaraderie, and repeat more corporate gospels. 
Secondly, in the form of initiatives to include pinning pictures, slogans and probably hand prints to notice boards, throwing sponges at management held in olde english 'stocks', like an end of school semester frustration venting session, and 'volunteer' days at weekends where more work is required, unpaid of course, to make the company look good in the eyes of some small sub-section of the local community.

- Always running 'one man too few'. Whether volume of parcels to deliver per day is low, average, high or at holiday season like hell made of brown cardboard, never having enough staff to cover the demand. This includes deliberately keeping drivers off road to keep costs down, lacking foresight or anticipation for spikes in volume, and having a high driver attrition rate. The outcome is that those drivers on road are under constant pressure to clear all daily deliveries beyond the acknowledged route capacity, as well as to help other drivers should they manage to do so. Result = Long hours & constant fatigue.

- Long serving, mostly long since productive and inefficient drivers get all the breaks, awards, help and preferential dates for time off.

- If you have management aspirations you must self elect. This means that the management enjoys generous helpings of verbosity, deception, hypocrisy, ego, chest puffing, patronizing vocal tones, insensitivity, self aggrandizement and other symptoms of extroversion, for you to rub shoulders with.

- Endless, un-cashable, verbal thank yous.

pros: Nice pay, nice benefits, it sometimes takes a very long time to become a full-time employee there though. Some people have worked 8 to 10 years part-time waiting for their turn to become full-time.
cons: Long hours, hard work. forced overtime on most days. There isn't a good work/home life balance at all there. The company seems to believe that instead of hiring more workers, that over time is the cheapest way to get the job done all year round.

pros: Good pay raises yearly, good benifits including amazing health insurance for you and your spouse  and your children. Tough it out and you'll make enough money to be set.
cons: Management is constantly putting people down. Work your hardest and its not good enough. Ups expects the impossible. Hot in summer months no air.

pros: They compensate their employees well. The company is well respected and it looks good on a resume if you accomplish something while working here.
cons: To often it feels like you are living to work instead of working to live. We spend a lot of time training employees but not so much on training management.

pros: Get back with me on this..........
cons: upper management is more interested in sitting behind a desk and saying get this number or else. They have no real concept of what we have to go through. TO ELITE to get down and ask the lower employees what they could do to help. Its all about the MONEY and bonus.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: Coworkers are alright. You learn some sales tactics during training. Good benefits. You're able to sit and stand at your desk. Elevators. Pay is okay if you're fairly new to the work world.
cons:
A LOT. This place sucks, I would STAY AWAY. The job description on their website is an outright lie and really misinforms people applying for the job. What you're really doing is cold calling people all day, many of whom don't want to talk to you. You are micromanaged and have to meet unobtainable sales goals every week or else you're put on "the list". 

Company is very behind with the times and stuck in the 1950's. They only have Internet Explorer 7 installed on the computers, and you have to use a MS-DOS program to find information about customers. Go look up MS-DOS... it's from 1981! And don't get caught eating chips at your desk. Only hard candy is allowed.

Then if you're a guy you have to shave everyday; not even a little stubble is allowed. You're talking to people on the phone... as in they can't see you... what the hell does it matter?

Then there's the commission which no one understands. It really makes absolute no sense. It's not just sell and make commission. They put in some many extra metrics and obstacles and no one understands it. Everyone just hopes that their commission check comes out decent.

And if this wasn't all bad enough, now they are having the ISR's and the Account Executives (the UPS employee actually in the area you are calling) competing against each other. You're not even a team anymore. So let's say you found a business and are trying to set up a UPS account with them, but the AE walks into the business and sets it up before you do, they get the commission money and you are out of luck. It's blasphemy!

job_title: Motor Control in Madison Heights, MI
pros: This is the only employer I know that offers full benefits to part-time workers. Everything, from health insurance to 401k is available to non-union workers immediately, and union workers after 1 year of employment.
cons: Wages aren't great, but better than minimum wage. Most of the job opportunities are night shift. I started work at about 3:00 a.m. and was done by 9 or so. During peak (Christmas), I sometimes started at about 10 at night and worked until 10 or 10:30 the next morning, but that means overtime.

pros: Very relaxed environment to work in. I worked with a great team that worked efficiently without being cutthroat. Great people who will look to help you with future employment upon a good internship experience for both sides.
cons: The office is slightly dreary. It's a very traditional office environment, and they have a large corporate structure, which makes it hard to move up in the company quickly.

pros: The work is steady and it keeps you busy.  The pay is okay and I enjoy working with the people at my hub.  I highly recommend getting on the sort line.
cons: The benefits as of now don't start until one year after your initial start date, so you have to be careful not to get hurt or sick in a way that might make you miss time at work.

pros: Package handling is an easy but demanding job. Start times at 3:45am can get grueling and peak seasons are even more demanding. Driver helper is optional during Christmas season which can equal $800 per week paychecks. Benefits are awesome! Your ambition can take you to a really good career at UPS.
cons: Off peak seasons can get pretty slim in pay. You will need another job most likely. Management can be slightly annoying sometimes but no big deal. UPS culture at this level is a a bit of a drag, and very physically demanding. Make sure you get plenty of sleep.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
All positions are part time, at 5 hours per day. Overtime is calculated as any day you work more than 5 hours. 

There's plenty of money to be made (at ~$10/hr), if you're willing to put in the time and effort. You can make a good deal of money during peak season (Christmas time). 

You can make $15/hr as a Driver Helper, which is ironic because you do significantly less work.
cons:
There's plenty of things to move up into, but you're going to have to be a peon for years before you'll get into a seniority position. 

Supervisors will get on your case for the smallest thing. They demand more than is required of you. (You are required, as per the union, to do at least 300 packages per hour. Supervisors will ask for 500 or more some days.) 

There is no flexibility with schedules whatsoever (Unless you are a driver helper). If you can't work a certain shift, you won't work that shift. 

If you are a student, you will practically kill yourself trying to work at UPS and do school at the same time. I would not recommend anyone try to work at UPS while going to school full time. I tried to do it myself, and I have quite literally almost died while driving home from exhaustion over 10 times. Working at UPS has cost me more time and sanity than it has been worth. I've made $7,000 while working there, and I have lost $15,000 as a result of it. 

Inefficiency and questionable choices are rampant with this place and it drives me insane.

There's a lot of people who occupy seniority decisions who are content to drag their feet and work slowly while the people on the low end of the ladder bust their butts for slave wages.

review_title: It is rough in the begining
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Benefits are great but you have to be here for at least a year to get the really good stuff. Such as healthcare dental, vision etc. Family plans are great as well. A lot of people work here solely for the benefits because its up there close to what the military gets. Yearly raises. Flexible work schedule for people who have other jobs as well for college students. The company has to work with you if you are in college. Meaning if you need to leave early or come in late then they will work with you. Just show them your class schedule. Job security due to being a union worker. Potential growth if your willing to stay for some time, 3-5 years on average to be a driver. Sometimes shorter and longer depending your hub and location. Pay is great once you become driver. Our feeders/truck drivers make 6 figures annually. Our package delivery drivers can make up to 35 dollars an hour. If driving isn't your thing you can always go the management route.
cons: Starting pay and hours are cut all the time combined that with Union Dues being taken out of your check in the beginning of every month. Required to work Sundays even its only for 2-3 hours. Management and supervisors are never happy. Takes a long time to become a driver. Extra hours/shifts are awarded in order of seniority not actual performance or work ethic. Meaning someone who has been at the hub for years who has become lazy can get extra hours and work over someone who is newer but work the hardest. Peak season is the only time where there are plenty of hours to go around. Peak season is from Thanksgiving until the last week of December at my hub. After peak our hours are cut back drastically. During peak season on a 10 dollar and hour salary I was bringing in 400 dollars a week. Then my first check during the month of January was 90 dollars(including the -40 union dues). That is to give you a perceptive on how inconsistent your weekly hours can get.  You either have to be a college student living off of loans to make ends meet or young enough to be living with your parents or have another part-time job. Or grateful enough to have a spouse that is willing to deal with your crappy income for a couple years until you qualify for a driver positions. During the summer the hub can get really hot meaning you will sweat a lot. Once your body gets used to the work the only problem after that is what trailer you will be loading. Some hubs have old fashion equipment which means extra work and effort being put forth. Some hubs have certain cities where trailers are filled with heavy car parts. Meaning you can be stuck loading/unloading 50-100 pounds items all day back to back or loading/unloading boxes from various sizes and weights. All are assigned by supervisors and or management. Takes a whole year just get your health benefits.

review_title: Great benefits, good pay after top pay
job_title: Pt Driver in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Benefits, Benefits,  PAY.  Company not only takes care of you but your entire family. Doctor visits $10 co-pay.  Pharmacy prescription  $5-10.  UPS pays 90% of hospital bill employee is responsible for the remaining 10%
cons:
Management 
part time - 3 to 4 hrs.
Full time opportunity after 1-3.5years

Management - alot of stress is put on them which trickles down to employees just like most giant corporation's now a days.

job_title: Package Delivery Driver in Addison, IL
pros: Good pay, good benefits. At least  those things were pluses when I worked there from 76 to 04.
cons: Management (managers and supervisors) and I were always at odds with each other in my 28 year career with  UPS. Eight of those years in package car and twenty in feeder.  They always talked safety out of one side of their mouth and speed in doing your job out of the other side. Everyone knew which one was most important to them. You might work your butt off, but if you took longer to do your days work than the computer said it should take you that day then you were in the office the next morning being grilled on what was the problem. In package car management would try to intimidate you to work faster. Some drivers would put on their time cards that they stopped for lunch for an hour, but in reality they kept delivering packages during that time, so, at the end of the day, on paper, it looked like they accomplished more. More deliveries in the hours worked. It was all a numbers game. I saw a number of drivers quit. Good workers. Couldn't take the constant pressure. Management didn't care because there were ten guys waiting at the door to get hired. Plus, good to get rid of a guy with four weeks vacation and train a new guy for two weeks and start the cycle all over again. No love lost for 95% of my supervisors and managers in my twenty eight years there.  I did my job, but most of the time they always wanted more and it's evidence that I did in fact do my my job because I'm sure they would have liked to have gotten rid of me because of times they would sneak around and spy on me while I was out making deliveries and their attempts to intimidate me into improving my numbers.  I always told them---"Ride with me and see how long it takes me and then if you see a problem there show me where or how to correct it." But, they usually just liked to sit in their office and accept the computers word on how long a any movement should take me.

review_title: Nope, I don't recommend. It's not for everyone.
pros: Great if you are just out of high school, going to college. They pay for college. If you can stand the environment for 30 years you can have retirement.
cons: If you are use to working in a decent environment, don't go to work here. It's like working with a bunch of large children who never grew up. Management and HR can't seem to get their act straight. They will tell you one thing, and it will happen another way. Don't expect management to cover for you. Even if you follow their directions perfectly and they were wrong they will try and find a way to pin it on you so always have documentation to cover yourself. That happened to me several times. One time several of us had a legitimate grievance so we went to the Union Stewart. When he came back from talking to management he told us we could continue the grievance but that management would be watching our every move waiting or us to make a mistake. Really? What's the point in having a Union if you can't use it and feel safe? Also, we had misloads EVERY DAY so we met up in parking lots to swap packages with other drivers which took a ton of time. If you were on a route you didn't know, you could end up not knowing which packages to give to another driver and therefore had to run it yourself at the end of the shift which could be way across the city of Houston. They hired me as a TCD and I would show up every day and if there wasn't work then I went home. After the peak season I was told to go home and they would call if they needed me so I didn't work for 4 weeks straight. Then they called and said I was "required" to work the warehouse if I wanted to stay employed. So they "required" me to go from making $29/hr to $10/hr just so I could have the privilege of occasionally running air, filling in for other drivers on vacation, and waiting for the next peak season 8-10 months later? And do this for 5 years until I can get a route? I mean if I was still living at home with my parents and going to college and didn't have a brand new baby, a mortgage, and a family to support that would be fine. But I can make more money doing something else and so that's exactly what I did.

review_title: They'll get their money's worth out of you
pros:
Benefits package- sounds great, the schooling reimbursement is very nice of them too. Medical and dental are after a year of working.
Paid time off- holiday and pto are great too, again after a year of work.
Part time hours- in theory this sounds great, you get lovely benefits for working part time, you work 4 hours a day and can do your own activities with the rest of your day!
-I did like this, but you get to wear your own clothes!
cons:
I can only speak as a part time package handler, loader. Here's my thoughts:
-you will be so tired most of your days you will be sleeping, trying to get your strength back to do it all over again.
-they don't pay well for what you do, so you will be extremely worn out and no way to treat any medical issues, unless you get another job but this job will wear you out.
-training is horrible. Maybe 2 hours total of videos(shown to you at 5am btw) and then it's off to the conveyor belt with you!
-you are expected to perform with the speed and accuracy of someone who's been doing it for 25 years immediately! 
-you can be promoted to management......if you've done 4 years of school. Otherwise it's part time promotion.
-they initially tell you it's about 4 hours a day but your arrival time gets pushed up. So let's say you are told "typically it's 4am to 8am" before your shift is over they will come to you and say "come in at 3am, now 2:45am, now 2:30am" and you may leave at 9am. By the time 8am hits you just want to leave!
-no lunches, just a 10 min break. So you come in thinking 4, you might do 7, no lunch! When you're hired you sign a meal waiver form.
-not just 70lbs you're lifting, I know I was lifting more than that several times! 
-they have no idea how to pace new hires. Can you sort one thing? How about three?! Can you load one van, how about four? Do these at the same time btw with 100% accuracy! 
-for what they expect out of you and what they take from you daily, I shouldn't be able to work a much cushier job and make the same to more. Pay your employees more! Especially if they have to wait. A year for the good stuff to kick in.
-this is not the military, you are not weeding out the weak with the insane workload, if I wanted to join the military I'd do just that.

review_title: Consider your end goal before applying
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Paid salary and hours are good while in training and if selected to start off in Enterprise. If selected for Enterprise, you can be there up to six months while salary is guaranteed. Good benefits package. If you're willing to relocate, this could work out for you, especially if an Account Executive position is open at one of your desired destinations. Veteran employees are very friendly and always willing to help. Specialists will go out of there way to help you. No weekends and you don't take work home. You will pick up some good sales skills here that will help your career.
cons: Middle Market department structure is Salary plus commission. Middle Market inside sales representatives have to work harder for their money. How well you do will have a lot to do with the territory you inherit, and the support structure you have in your geographical area.  Commission structure has variables that are changed often in order to make it harder to hit goal. This place is run like the wild west without corporate ever truly knowing what goes on here. Management team follows whatever he says and will not back you up when you need it. HR team will sweep things under the rug without corporate knowing. You will manage many accounts, but will not feel empowered in Enterprise or training, unless you are in middle market. Stress level in middle market is high along with pay that is usually less than Enterprise. This has led to high turnover, or people taking short term disability for stress. Many good employees have fled for other opportunities or just left the company. Account Executive positions are constantly opening up nationwide, because of high turnover. Many get promoted well before they are ready. More often than not, they are selected because they need bodies as not many applied for the open territory position. This is why Inside Sales is always hiring.

review_title: Management Jobs in UPS - Every person in the company is screwed over. That's where it starts.
job_title: Part Time Package Center Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: better pay than bottom of the barrel. Better pay than any other shipping company actually.
cons:
If you go into management you get screwed over left and right and down the middle and crossways. People get hired off the street, unprofessional people to fill bad dead-end truck loading jobs. These are the same people who wind up becoming your manager and division manager. These people, bless their hearts, are given impossible tasks to complete while critical staff and tools are witheld from their use. It is from this point that these people DO NOT CARE about any part time package center supervisor in the driver centers. They themselves are abused and do not care about your welfare because they have nothing left for themselves. If you don't hold your manager accountable you will get 1/2% raise. If you don't talk to your manager about what HE THINKS how you are doing on your job you will get screwed for an entire year with a 1% raise which is very bad in an economy where all the prices you pay for things for yourself goes up  at about 3% per year. TIP: IF YOUR MANAGER RATES YOU AS "NEEDS IMPROVMENT" HR AUTOMATICALLY ASSIGNS YOU 1% RAISE FOR THE YEAR. now since you work as a team sometimes someone else screws up and the blame gets assigned to you. You have to catch that stuff immediately and go over it with your manager. Do not go over it with your full-time supervisor, they don't care or won't communicate it usually to the manager. 

Something to think about: UPS cannot compete with companies like amazon or cheaper shippers.  They all just pay a lot less to their employees. They don't offer benefits, paid vacation, 401k matching, etc.The result is UPS is always trying to squeeze out the workers and go full automation in the hubs to cut costs and compete. Automation is currently ramping up and workers getting layed off by the droves.

review_title: Do you enjoy being screamed at all day?
job_title: Operations Supervisor in Whites Creek, TN
pros: Good benefits and great hours
cons:
Only 1 single 10 minute break regardless of how many hours you work in a day. Sounds pretty shady, right? Yeah. It is. 

Everything is your fault. Don't meet production on your shift even though you did exactly what you were told. 

Your job basically consists of asking hourly, union, employees to work faster, which they are under no obligation to do. When they don't work faster you are told that you don't know how to do your job. Sometimes you are asked to "demonstrate" to employees who have been there 10+ years. Union rules state that as management you are not to do any work, so you are supposed to tell someone to step aside so they can watch you as you demonstrate, which they often will not let you do. So, you are *wink wink* asked to demonstrate, which means you need to work, but you weren't exactly told to work, but you know that that's what your boss wants you to do. Then when you get filed on for working management does not have your back, and instead will suspend you. 

No training either. You aren't told how to manage people. You are taught how to fill out paperwork, and that's basically it. Management barely knows how to manage the other part-time managers. 

There is so much micro-management going on here it will make your head spin. Ever had 4 different people telling you 4 different, contradicting, things to be doing at once? That's just another day here. 

As management, you aren't even allowed to make any management decisions. You are there to be told that you are not doing your job. You will have a radio strapped to you so that these lovely reminders of how terrible you're doing can be shouted into your ear by every upper-management person under the sun. 

Employees will not listen to you, because why would they? There are no repercussions for their actions. They walk out when they want, or don't do as you ask them? Your fault.

job_title: Operation Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best part is the compensation. No one else in the logistics industry compensates their employees, management or non-management, as well as UPS. Additionally, it is very difficult to get fired even if you are in management and are the worst performer. They generally try to just make you quit if you aren't cut out for it. However, if you are good and are willing to do the work and take all the cons then this place will reward you and you will get promoted far quicker than at other logistics operations.
cons: Very long hours and little to no appreciation. Upper management only talks about what you can do better. Even though upper management knows nothing about running your center they still like to get involved and ruin everything. My center in San Francisco was ranked #1 Urban Center in the nation, and we got there by ignoring their orders and doing what we knew was right. Sadly our hard work was repaid by having my best supervisors get transferred to terribly performing centers. If you are a top performer, you are moved continuously around even against your will. They say it's to help you learn as much of the business as possible, but it just satisfies their needs instead of yours, because your bonuses are tied directly to your current center. So to go from a top performing center to one with bad numbers means losing your bonus. Think about that having to work harder in a new area and getting paid less. However, upper management said they will address that issue by increasing our base pay and removing bonuses! Then what is the point of being a top performer if you get paid the same as everyone else? I think that is my biggest gripe with the company other than the constant yelling at all levels of the business. I hear on conference calls supervisors in underperforming centers get berated and verbally abused for their numbers. They, in turn, yell at their employees, which is how you hear about all these part-time employees complaining about getting yelled at.

review_title: My Experience as a Seasonal Preloader
pros: Some of the managers were great at their job in training you. Some of the Co-workers were also motivated enough to assist you as a newcomer. Pre-loading position offers an early enough work schedule that allows for you to be done with the hardest work of your day early in the morning. It's great hours for early risers, and allows you to be able to work on other important projects during daylight hours if you need to. For those who appreciate keeping physically active while they work - this may be the job for you. You can get well over 10,000 steps in within a 5+ hour work shift.  Remember to not strain yourself with lifting boxes that are too heavy without asking for assistance. Follow UPS attire guidelines; especially as it relates to the shoes, as best you can because this will protect YOUR feet in the event you lift a heavy box that has not been taped sufficiently and the bottom opens up and contents fall out! Free health insurance if you get hired on as a regular employee (after 9 months!)
cons: If you are not lucky enough to get hired during a time or location that has helpful co-workers or managers, you will not be trained sufficiently, which will leave the drivers of the trucks you load frustrated for the rest of their day. During the UPS rush season - most of the managers are too frustrated or distracted to provide sufficient training to newcomers. They also sometimes assume that those they hire that have worked for other companies such as Fedex will know how to do the job - which is not true. Most importantly; UPS seems to not care much about making sure they calculate your hours correctly. You had best to keep track of your schedule and check behind whomever enters your work hours if you want to be sure that you are getting paid for all hours and minutes worked. When the holiday rush was over, they called us in for a couple days then literally laid us off prematurely and abruptly without any advance notice; (they told us at end of January we would be done.) This showed a great lack of concern for employees that helped them out during their busiest season of the year and have bills to pay.  We seasonals were hired on with incorrect information about how much our hourly wage would be.  It was much less. Hiring managers were helpless it seemed; as the change was tied up in union and corporate red tape. The FREE insurance will not kick in until you have become a full-time or regular employee for nine months; that does not include the months that you worked as a seasonal worker! The company is reportedly dealing with corporate instructions to cut back on their expenses - so they send some workers home early when they are done with what they usually do- instead of sending them to help with the overload of work that other employees have on their hands.  They also did not hire on some of us that were proven hard workers with great work ethics. We were told corporate may not be hiring on regulars as much as in the past or at all. This could have been our facility only or country wide - not sure.

pros: The benefits for a part-time employee at UPS are exceptional. You will have to wait awhile for them to set in depending on the current contract. An increase in pay every year with a cap at 5 years is nice. I am a loader which requires me to put a large amount of packages into a sem-trailer in a relatively short amount of time. It is relatively simple. Their are all kinds of safety events to get free t-shirts at UPS. The work itself is much like a workout, with emphasis on the back and legs.
cons:
Well there are a lot of problems that one will encounter as a part-timer. You basically have no pull until you put in around 2-3 years at UPS or unless you memorize a lot of zip codes to get pumped up in job class to a pickoff/sorter. Loading and Unloading are two separate animals with different problems. The one I know well is the job of a loader, and it is very stressfull. Every day the manager will reveal your performance, mostly looking at how many scans you had per hour and how many errors you made(misloads). The problem with this system is that their are literally hundreds of scenarious you will face that will diminish each of these evaluators. One being your manager will make you take cart fulls of packages to the missort belt, killing your scans per hour. Another problem occurs if you are in a very slow chute/ have to help break jams for other loaders/pick 70 plus pound irregs off the floor. The real issue it the misload situation, as too many will lead any new hire to a termination. I have just recently gotten past my first 30 days without a misload to my name to acquire senior status. That may not seem like a big deal to most, but during this period I was "salted"(purposely given incorrect packages by management) at least 30 times a night.. It is part of the job I understand, but when loaders often help other loaders scan or use their scanner it creates an opportunity for disaster. When your supervisor asks you for your scanner you are pretty much trusting him with your job. 

Ok another con of the job is the obvious weird hours. Kiss your loved ones goodbye plus any possible semblance of a normal life if you choose to do the Night shift or Sunrise shift. And really, if you are working at UPS during the other two shifts you should reevaluate how important this company is to you. I have another job in addition to attending my master's program. The only reason I work at UPS is because of the weird hours but at the same time they are my undoing. I feel like a zombie on my days off. As far as UPS being all that bad in terms of management, I don't really think that is true. It is very typical of a large company to have underqualified leaders, so one should just be prepared. They care about you, but just like anyone they are looking for the next big thing. The start times of work also change almost daily so that makes it very difficult to not WASTE time in the parking lot or in the hub at your PD.

I have heard that unloading is very difficult. They have to move much faster than we do as loaders and are expected to be able to position packages correctly regardless of their weight. Less time means less pay thus making it important to evaluate time in transit to work. 

This is a workout but not one that will get you muscular. Well, besides your back. But God help you when it gives out. Your forearms will spazz on you after awhile. You will sweat terribly and lose weight. I eat like Michael Phelps now and I still cannot keep up as I went from 188 lbs. to barely 170 lbs. in about 3 months time of working as a loader. Worse yet is that you cannot workout after doing this, so they tell you "its like getting paid to work out" but it doesn't make any sense.
Overrall I wouldn't do this if I were you, and I plan on getting out sooner than later.

review_title: Overall, not a bad temp job..
pros:
While the job that I initially applied for was 'Driver Helper', I was instead assigned an area with a golf cart, a trailer hooked up to said golf cart, and a POD. Drivers would be dispatched to my POD and the packages would be placed in the POD. I'd sort the packages, load them up into my cart/trailer, and deliver them by hand to people's houses throughout a greater neighborhood.

I got lucky. My particular area was in a nice and shady, richy-rich country club area. Even on the busiest days on my route, I'd typically never go over five hours of work time. The people that lived there were (typically) friendly, but the employees rarely were. There wasn't much traffic, even for a country club, so there was rarely any traffic. If you're looking for a job where you can work temporarily, work by yourself and at your own pace, this is the kind of job you're looking for.

Just, again, note that I got lucky. On a few unfortunate days, I was forced to jump for a driver, and on several occasions we'd stop to help other cart jumpers with their loads. A single cart driver can have a literal gigantic steel shipping container FULL of packages. One poor individual had so much in his container that even after working from 9 AM to almost dark, he still had hundreds of stops left. So be warned that your experience can and will vary. I intend to attempt to work temp for UPS again for the holidays in 2014, as well, in the hopes that I again get the same route I'd been doing this year.

Working for the company was, for the most part, smooth. I saw another reviewer on this website that complained about the fact that they were given paper paychecks instead of direct deposit. They warned me right off the bat this would be the case and that direct deposit (and other benefits) was/were only for part-time and full-time employees, not for temp help.

If you need some extra holiday money, want to get your foot in the door at UPS and aren't adverse to working out all day and getting paid to do it, then consider applying for temp help.
cons:
The workload is ridiculous, and there aren't enough people to handle the workload. This is why you'll often hear stories of drivers (and helpers) staying out WAY past dark just to get their deliveries all done. These are all true. If you're looking for a short job that'll net you some extra holiday cash, be wary that many days you'll be working a MINIMUM of eight hours. I got lucky in that my route as a cart jumper was light enough that I was done in four to five hours most days.

They tell you that you need to be able to lift more than 70 lbs. in order to do the work, but on SEVERAL occasions I was forced to move 80+ lbs. packages SEVERAL times throughout the day, and not trivial distances, either. I also had to lift these over several feet to load them onto my cart's trailer. This meant they had to be lifted in AND out. UPS states that these packages need to be team lifted, and that these instances are 'errors', but I think they're full of it. I can't count the days on both hands when I had several packages over 70 lbs..

Again, the workload is ridiculous, and not just for you, but also for their operations people. The UPS place near my house that gave me general training is a surprisingly small operation for such a large place, and having been in their office, they're clearly lacking the room needed to function properly. I can't help but wonder how many shipping centers are like this. It is, to say the least, an enormous mess.

As a result, there will be days when you'll be sitting there as a cart jumper wondering when they're going to call you to meet your driver at the POD. There were more than a few days when I had to call THEM to remind them I existed. Their inconsistency as an operation upset me on more than one occasion. In addition, I was forced a total of three separate times to go acquire a uniform from them. Once when I began, another time after I was told to turn in my uniform on Christmas Eve and they needed me in the days following, and then again the day after New Years Day.

Whether you're driver helper or cart helper, you're going to run into adverse weather eventually. Living in Florida, there were several days in which it rained. Cold, freezing rain. I was given nothing to potentially protect my packages, and I'm honestly surprised after standing in the pouring, freezing rain for several hours that I didn't catch pneumonia, let alone a cold.

The golf cart operations are iffy at best. There are many days when you'll wonder if your golf cart is even going to work properly. I was lucky in that my golf cart only failed once, and when it failed, it was a catastrophic failure. It wouldn't move. I had to have the cart completely replaced with a 'new' one, by that I mean, an old one. I was informed that these carts are poorly maintained after the holiday rush and then left in storage for the rest of the year. If the cart drives the next year when it's time to get them out to their locations, then it's good to go. It shows.

So while the job is hectic, it's good money (I got paid $8.50 when I was told I'd be paid $8.25 - not a huge amount, but hey, money's money), you just need to understand fully what you're getting yourself into, because the people recruiting are so desperate for temporary help that they don't feel the need to fully warn you about what to expect. They also love to tempt you with the prospect of being fully hired onto the team, when your chances of getting hired no matter how amazing your performance is are slim to none.

pros:
The benefits package is decent, even at entry level positions. If you are a union employee, I believe it takes a year of seniority before you are eligible for medical and dental coverage though.

If you can work your schedule around school, the earn and learn program helps pay for some of your tuition costs. Make sure your school is covered by the program first though. Typically, you will still need to pay a considerable amount of money out of pocket or obtain a loan, but the extra coverage does help.
cons:
Unless you are a driver or upper management, the salary is not great. But if you do fall into one of those categories, you will likely work 60+ hours a week. During the last quarter, that will likely jump to 70+ hours and holidays, since that is the company's peak season. 

Front-line management are often younger people who are working their first managerial positions. Due to high turnover in both the managerial and hourly workforces within the company, this often leads to inexperienced supervisors leading a group of jaded, high seniority union employees. Unsurprisingly, this is not the greatest combination as far as work environment and culture.

Until you reach upper management levels, almost every position is based in a warehouse environment. Being in a warehouse with a lot of running machinery, poor ventilation, and no air conditioning often means you will be physically uncomfortable for most of your job, especially during the summer months.

Because hourly employees are union-based, seniority is the only thing that matters as far as compensation. This often creates a workforce that is complacent. This is further perpetuated by the fact that if people work slower, there is obviously more work left to be done-- and if there is more work to be done, the higher seniority people are allowed the first bid on that work by union contract. There is nothing wrong with trying to make more money, but this is an inherent flaw in the system that is easily and often exploited.

Career opportunities usually rather for people who are long time in company than for people who are short time but more skilled.
