pros: They will accept people on short notice. The hiring process is relatively simple and hassle free. The work was straight forward and simple. Enjoyed working with the drivers.
cons: Had a bit of difficulty receiving my last paycheck from them, but management was able to step in and assist. Was also misled about receiving overtime pay. As it turned out, seasonal helpers don't qualify for an increased pay rate for doing OT, which I found out after putting in the work.

review_title: The job is tough but not impossible.
pros: Hours every day so there is a consistent schedule. You work with straight forward hard working people. The job challenges you , and you work as a team.
cons: The supervisors take their job way too seriously. You're always fatigued after work. In addition you have to do the same thing every day. There is no diversity in the position. And over all no genuine satisfaction at the end of the night.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in New Stanton, PA
pros:
- great opportunity for  those willing to work hard and actually sweat
- tuition reimbursement of 1500$ per semester
- part time hours, full time benefits
- great workout
cons:
- outdated equipment and facilities make it a dangerous job
- union ensures that lazy employees are paid equivalently to hardworking individuals
- union also ensures that long time employees receive preferential treatment, at the expense of new hires

review_title: It's okay but there's always better.
job_title: Package Handler in Earth City, MO
pros:
The Work is fast pace and hands on.

The part-time workers are friendly and hard working.

It's a great workout
cons:
You work almost the full amout of hours but not quite the exact hours.

Management is very pushy urging workers to speed up or work harder despite there being no realistic way too.

Management is seemingly more focused on production and meeting their downtimes, rather than setting realistic managable time goals and pace goals.

Very little time is focused on working to figure out and strengthen a employees strengths, and more attention is usually shed on the weaknesses.

There's a lack of communication between supervisors and workers, this leads employees to feel supressed by supervisor to not speak up about issues or complains they may be having.

Really heavy volume is expected to move out at a near superhuman pace, often leading to workers fatigue.

Poor work enviorment

pros:
Somewhat decent hours for college students. 
Decent pay/benefits. 
Looks good on resume as middle management.
cons: There is absolutely no checks and balances for the full time supervisors and the decisions they make in the hubs. They can operate in whatever manner they want. I've had full timers who can and has written up part time employees for drinking soda because it was "unhealthy " even though it's a very physically difficult job during third shift which caffeine is almost necessary at times. Getting promoted is based SOLELY on how much you brown nose with the upper management. Oh, you work harder than everyone else? Doesn't matter, you won't get promoted without sucking up. The full timers have absolute control over who gets promoted (which makes sense and works in theory) but is disastrous when they are clueless to the specific job field that employee is in. To summarize, don't work hard, play the system, suck up to management, and then you can get promoted. Working my butt off harder than everyone else trying to get promoted has given me some insite in these 2 past years.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Chino Valley, AZ
pros: I found UPS to be a Fortune 500 company with excellent benefits and great schedule and excellent pay.
cons: The lines of communication for my department at times were weak and the training was slow in coming. They did get the people hired for the department we needed and things were moving along at a good pace before moving to different city.

review_title: Terrible environment and culture.  Good for school and then out.  Hub and Airport locations
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good benefits, Pay is very good (in terms of dollar amount, not value) Tuition Reimbursement, Easy work, Salary pay up to 27.5 hours (average of 23 worked hours) and then paid hourly after you hit 27.5 hours (only time is during peak)
cons: Cant work more hours to get more pay (pay checks are exactly the same every week), upper management is terrible in that it micromanages, treats lower level employees very poorly by literally YELLING at people, expect you to devote your life to UPS - even as a part-time supervisor, blame game is very common.  They do a lot of this with the excuse of being for the customer, when in reality it boosts their own stock and paycheck at the end of the year. Immature atmosphere with gossiping, whining about things not being fair, etc.  Mindless sheep everywhere with no initiative to ever ask "why" and when someone does, they are shunned and looked at as a problem causer.  Upper management NEVER listens to ideas from lower employees, only take orders from upper management.  No upward mobility, and if there is a chance to be promoted, management will not help you.  They want to keep you where you are in order to save themselves the "headache" of replacing you.  You NEVER hear a management level, or any employee here talk about how they love their job, even THEY talk about hating their job.  This is true with 90% of UPSers.

pros: This job is very straightforward and easy to learn. The union offers great benefits after you qualify for them. There's also opportunity for advancement.
cons: Working in the elements can be tough for some folks. The trucks are the same temperature as outside, so its extremely cold in the winter/hot in the summer. This is a very labour intensive position so if your not in some what decent shape you may struggle. This is not a full time position. The HR department is incompetent to say the least.

pros: I absolutely love working at this place. I love all the colors! Im on orange belt. I get to load a truck and two cars and one of my favorite pastimes is package swimming. Whatever your dream job is FORGET ABOUT IT! UPS is where all hopes and dreams are fulfilled! Apply TODAY!
cons: Not Enough bulk stops on my truck, add about three more warehouses and were good to go.

review_title: If you go into management, make sure you're doing it for the right reasons.
pros:
Good rapport and camaraderie within the part time supervisors group
Great benefits package
Challenging in so many ways, really pushes you to your limits and forces you to grow as a person and managing so many different types of personalities will only benefit you in future endeavors
The full time management team tries to do a good job of instilling the company's core values into all of us and a lot of the stuff they talk about does help to foster better relationships with hourly employees.
cons: Tough, demanding job. Union makes some things much harder than they should have to be but I understand why they're a necessity within the company. There is potential for a career within the company but you need to put up with a lot of BS for a few years in order to get there. Little to no work life balance as many shifts are extremely inconvenient. Most days you leave feeling like you just got the crap kicked out of you even if you were successful on that day. Some of the people who work for you are simply outright hostile towards you. Can only try to kill them with kindness and competency. Pay sucks and they cap your hours as a supervisor even if you have to work more than the hours allowed.

job_title: Seasonal Warehouse "Car Washer" in Chantilly, VA
pros:
The online application was pretty quick and self explanatory. I even scheduled my interview as the last step.
The mass interview and on boarding were pretty uncomplicated too.
The work was pretty intense and fun.
The weather was unexpectedly warm for December.
Given that we were running all over the warehouse every night, the lady who was responsible for all of our initial and ongoing safety and other training/orientation was very diligent about hunting us down and getting it done over our short part-time month on the job. 
The managers who were pitching in for holiday season were pretty friendly and made an effort to reach out and welcome us.
Most full time and seasonal employees seemed disappointed (in a good way) by how smooth and organized the season was. 
I was personally choosing work/life imbalance by going for this seasonal job.
cons:
There could have been some take/carry aways from the first day on the job that were personalized to us. (1) It wasn't clear who our direct supervisor actually was (it didn't change our work, but it made communicating about our work schedules (coming from day jobs) more confusing than necessary. Some of the pre-requisite training and benefits paperwork was also confusing. 
In the beginning, they made the pledge: "We do make offers and keep the good ones when it is all over, IF we have openings." It came off a little dubious. 
The regular UPS employees at the warehouse and the drivers were all so excited and a little nervous about the annual holiday chaos that they were a lot harder to connect with.

review_title: Great for students and in between occupations
pros: The tuition reimbursement is hard to beat. You don't have to take your work home with you. You have a pretty consistent schedule.
cons: Can be dangerous and physically strenuous. Hard to get off during winter holidays. Either early morning or late evening shifts at my location make living normal life hard.

review_title: Worth it if you can hang in there
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Sioux City, IA
pros: Great to work for as a driver. I started loading trucks, which is what you have to do before becoming a driver. Solid people working there. No crazies or felons or the like. Just red blooded hard working folks.
cons:
If you are intending to be a driver, which is the highest paid positions there (and probably one of the highest in the country), you're just going to have to put up with their you-know-what. Forget other jobs you may have. THEY will have to schedule around UPS time. Remember, it's logistics. Packages go out every day and they need reliable people (read: "company man") to be there every day. If you're lucky enough to be in a place where you'll only be a package handler for a short while before becoming a driver, then by all means suck it up and do it. If you're like me and $10 an hour working part time won't pay your bills while you wait to become a driver, then forget it. 

Here is how I would do it if I had to again: First, start young. You need to be in shape for package handling, AND you may have quite a wait before becoming a driver. If you're 40 and a smoker like me all I can say is you're going to have a tough go of it. Second, save your money now so you have a little financial help when you need it since you won't be making much to start. Having a second job is a possible answer, but seems to work best for morning crew (I got stuck on evening shift).

By the way, my four star rating is because for being a logistics company, communication wasn't that good. I was told I'd have a week to notify my employer of my UPS schedule. They started me day 1 after the interview and since we worked a bit late that night I was late to work at my other job. They expected the same the next day even though I explained that technically I was not to start until the next week. I showed up, worked a few hours, and let them know when I'd have to leave for my other job. They basically advised me that it was either UPS or no UPS. When I told them the agreement I had with my interviewer, they said he went home for the night . I basically felt pressured to "prove myself" on the one hand, and worried about paying my bills on the other should I be forced to quit my other job. I obviously chose to continue paying the bills.

pros:
One of the greatest pros about working for The UPS store is you make connections and get a good networking system going on. Networking is key. Many UPS stores have mailboxes and many of the mailbox holders talk to and rely on the staff on a regular basis. Many of the mailbox holders were some of the more wealthy people in town that own businesses that could be of interest to you. 

Another thing is you learn a lot of skills that could help you in any industry you pursue. UPS stores work with lots of rich people that need help figuring out how to print, design, or do simple tasks on  a computer. You learn how to do these things. 

You also learn a lot about shipping that you never thought possible. It helps you to know the best ways to ship things and what to ship them in. 

You always have good hours. It's not a store that stays open late into the night. You have more opportunities to work early in the morning and get off early in the evening. 

Depending on the time of year, you don't always have much to do around the store. Some months are really slow and you could do homework or surf the web.

If you've worked in customer service before, this job is a piece of cake, because the real task is pleasing and working with customers.
cons:
People come in the store grumpy about their shipments if they didn't get to their destination on time or if it had gone missing. 

Many people also don't realize that a UPS store is a franchise. Therefore, they think you represent the whole UPS company and can access every single thing about their packages and change anything we want to, but we can't due to privacy issues and policies. 

Customer service is key in this field of work and if you're not good and efficient at customer service, you might struggle in this job. 

Sometimes it gets really busy and that can be stressful because the UPS Store needs to be faster than a post office.

pros: easy hire, interview was straight forward. Good working environment, friendly atmosphere. the job was pretty easy. We loaded boxes from a massive conveyor belt into the UPS truck for delivery
cons: shift availability. There was not much room to transfer to earlier shift times. The drive for me was a little long, Could have used some instruction on how to load a truck for maximum us of space.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Edison, NJ
pros: Didn't find a single "Pro" the 2 short months I was there before resigning.
cons:
Oh...where to start. You are considered an "Industrial Athlete" and you will be sore for the first month you work there because your body is not used to the particular labor that you will be doing, this is all fine. The issue comes in when they mark your "Packages Per Hour" (PPH) because it will NEVER be good enough for the supervisors (if they even mark it correctly, I called out one night because I had an emergency, when I came back I had to sign my "Cornerstone Progress Book" that had a PPH tally for the day I was out).

You will have multiple part-time supervisors telling you to do different things while they come back and tell you not to do what the other supervisor said. They will yell at you to keep the pathway clear of packages but sadly it is almost impossible at some points. When you tell the unloader to stop their belt for 2 minutes to clean the pathway the supervisor will tell them to start it then yell at you to clear the floor (kind of difficult when you have packages coming at you). 

When the suggestion was made to maybe pair unloaders and sorters with similar PPH I got a stupid look of "why would I do that." WELL! Lets see, if the unloader unloads 1300 packages in an hour and the sorter can only sort 1200...there will be a problem thru the shift. 

They claim to be people friendly but I didn't see that, I had a box slam into the back of my head after another employee placed it on the belt wrong, the supervisor managed to see the box come down the belt and hit the ground...but missed the moment of impact to my head, and when asked how he didn't see it....he just didn't. 

The pay is absolutly below what should be paid for the position, they advertise certain work schedules but change the start and end time almost daily.

I have worked with so many bad supervisors between my time in the military and civil service, I only took this job for extra cash but their supervisors take the cake on how bad they actually are, they have no clue how to interact with their staff or actually manage. I honestly think a 12 year old could make better sense of things. As someone who has been a supervisor, and still is at my full time job, if I supervised even close to them I would have been fired. 

Also, for a company that strives to be about the customer, its truly shocking how many damaged boxes are considered "lost value" by management, someone paid for that merchandise.

The CEO started as a part time package handler, its apparently been years and he needs to get back in the saddle and see what actually occurs in his hubs because no one has a clue, my hub was built in the 80's to handle 10-14,000 packages a DAY, we handle almost double that in a SHIFT!

Not worth the stress, pay or benefits (that you get after a year).

pros: Similar People with the same interests (Finishing college/work ethics), Opportunities in better pay, Health Insurance coverage after one year of service, and break rooms for the package handlers that bring their lunch.
cons: Late Night Work, Hard Labor, Easily Injured If Not Careful, Formed Cliques, High School Drama, Flexible Times, Work Holidays, Can't Take Vacation Days During Peak Season, Unfair Management, Strict Supervisors That Perform Poorly, and LOTS OF DEPRESSION. Note: When there isn't work to do, there's nothing to do. You can get paid better just to watch paint dry.

pros: Great workout so you're getting paid to get stronger. Decent wage with opportunities to advance.
cons: Their system is set up so that packages often come down the line so quickly and so many at once that chaos tends to happen several times a day where packages end up getting stacked out or roughly handled where a slower or just more organized line would really help that.

pros:
You will get into shape.  You get a lot of thank you's from customers. You get to use your skills at logistical planning.  Good Pay.  Flexible lunches. Intrinsically rewarding. UPS invests a lot of on training programs to assist in career advancement. They also encourage the advancement of educational goals, offering a program that allows you to earn $5,250 in assistance per calendar year of your college education, for those eligible.  Prior to starting your job, the training needs to improve. This is a physical, fast-paced, outdoor position that involves continual lifting, lowering and carrying packages that typically weigh 25 - 35 lbs. and may weigh up to 110 lbs. A DOT physical exam is required. Package Delivery Drivers must have excellent customer contact and driving skills.  Some UPS facilities may require the ability to drive a delivery vehicle with a standard (manual) transmission. Qualified applicants must have a valid drivers license issued in the state that they live. Package Delivery Drivers are expected to comply with UPS appearance guidelines and wear the company-provided uniform. 
Full-time UPS employees work eight or more hours each weekday (Monday through Friday) and typically do not work on weekends or selected holidays. An applicant or employee may request an exception or change to, or an accommodation of, any condition of employment (including the UPS Uniform and Personal Appearance Guidelines) because of a sincerely held religious belief or practice. UPS hires workers in the following six major functional clusters:  Package Handlers and Helpers, Drivers and Mechanics, Customer Solutions and Sales, IT, Corporate, and Logistics and Operations.  Work days are at-least 8 hours. Typically 9.5hrs to 10hrs.  It depends on the dispatch and knowledge of the route by the driver.
cons: Running in the snow is hazardous to your health. A bad dispatch will ruin your day.  The truck are loud (inside).  Every dog within 50 miles will hear you coming and start licking their chops. Training could be improved.  Giving us just a couple of each of the 344 transaction the DIAD can do in 4.5 days is not enough time.

pros: the pay is awesome and benefits no other company can compete with oh ya the pay is awesome
cons: long hours never get told good job if you get on the bad side of bosses they will come for you

pros: Excellent benefits, some really cool people to work with
cons:
Having to get up in the wee hours of the morning...but being done by 9am was nice and you'd have the rest of the day free.  
Harassment from certain management was excessive.  Even when you excelled and did an excellent job overall, you could still be harassed simply for doing something different than everyone else (even though it was better).  You were required to fit into their cookie-cutter system and if you strayed in any way you'd be a target, no matter how well you did your job.

pros: Competitive benefits with a lot of room for advancement. Focused on career development. Opportunities to work with others on projects.
cons:
60+ hour work weeks
Due to downsizing, what was once 5 people's job is now 1 persons
A lot of useless meetings
Having to work in several locations, my home base was moved 3 times, with my last base being almost 50 miles away
Little to no training
Industrial engineering is fun, the rest of the company was not

review_title: As a supervisor I would rather kill myself.
job_title: PT Supervisor/Loader in New Stanton, PA
pros: The people are wonderful. Before I became a supervisor I would have given it 4 stars. It was a great workout and I was moderately happy
cons: Management, will treat you like you are a pile of dung. My direct fulltime supervisor threatened to fire me three times in the two weeks I was a supervisor. I was given no real training and was thrown on a belt. Had to rely on other supervisors to hold my hand when they weren't busy.  The conditions in which you work in aren't bad, but you're outside, even though you're inside.  Sonetimes in the trailers its colder or hotter than it is outside.

pros:
Tuition program (its a voucher program and not reimbursement, really nice for college students)
Insurance offered to sups after 30 days of employment
No weekends (this is changing, Saturdays will be required soon)
Pay rate is decent, raise given after 6 months
401K with good company match 
Company puts money into HSA if you opt for it
UPSers website is really useful and full of good info
Safety is a big priority to the company
If you're willing to relocate there can be some growth
PT Supervisors are given vacation immediately
5 Discretionary days off to use a year
Paid holidays
cons: Your work environment will depend largely on your FT management, and how strict the union is.  Full-time supervisors consistently throw the PT sups under the bus in front of employees, and upper management does the same to the FT sups. Unrealistic goals to hit, you're blamed when slow employees can't keep up and you're not allowed to help them. Moving from PT to FT management is difficult and can take many years, company likes hiring fewer and fewer FT sups and replace them with PT. You will have to relocate to advance. In our center we can't find candidates to promote to sups because they see the way we're treated.  Many employees with high seniority are entitled and come across as whiny babies, especially the drivers.  Rampant favoritism is shown by upper management. Saturday ground delivery is coming this year, and with it our weekends. Some PT sups will be working 6 day work weeks.  Do not take this job unless you have thick skin and can take being treated poorly by people above and below you.

pros: Competitive pay but it is rare to get more than about 20-24 hours per week and the union gets some of that money. During 'peak' season you will get A Lot of hours, and you may struggle to rest and recover adequately. You will get Exercise. Depending on your level of fitness, you may require a lot of time to recover. Benefits are good but you must tolerate one year there to become eligible for benefits.
cons: Unreasonable expectations - they want humans to work like machines; go faster, do more, faster, faster...oh and be safe in a building that is always a dehydrating sweatbox. It is often difficult to move packages quickly because there are many of them and they often weigh over 100 pounds, yet they expect clear walk paths at all times; even when there is no place to put the packages. They expect package handlers to do a lot of work as fast as possible then drivers are upset by inevitable 'crazy' loads. Package Handlers are rushed to finish quickly, often leaving drivers with disorganized loads, so the drivers then spend a lot of their day rearranging their loads; and the drivers make a lot more money than package handlers make. UPS is full of 'time eaters'. 'Time eaters' that remove you from your work occur daily and take anywhere from about 5 minutes to 30 minutes or more and only mess up your process, because when you are not doing your work, your work is not getting done. Short meetings occur daily. Longer meetings include surveys, training sessions and other windbaggery. They care about worker injuries because injuries can cost the company a lot of money.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Landover, MD
pros: Some of the drivers are fun to work with. Lots of exercise! And uniforms are provided.
cons: They are very strict. They are strict about attendance and strict about uniforms and hair/shoes. If you don't have enough availablity in the holiday season, they let you go and mark your name as a "do not rehire".

pros: Show up, load up the trucks, then leave. Nice, straightforward work.
cons: Can be difficult at times. During the holiday seasons, it gets crazy. Not a job for everyone, you need to stay focused and load nonstop for a long period of time.

pros: No late night hours. Looks great on a resume because people think the center is associated with corporate.
cons: High stress, and low pay. Lots of work and minimal staff. For the amount of work that is expected of an associate, it is not worth minimum wage.

job_title: Account Manager in New York, NY
pros: Competitive salary, good coworkers, opportunity to learn about other industries through sales, decent learning opportunities IE negotiations, computer skills.
cons: Company does not work with employees for work/life balance.  There is a lot of red tape to get things approved and accomplished when in sales.  It is hard to launch ideas for new products and services to corporate and upper management.

review_title: I wish I never wasted my time.
pros: The money that they paid you was okay, only because you worked 12-14hrs everday.
cons:
Trained for 3 days in a class on paper memorizing ridiculous sentences, put on a truck after 3 days shadowing. The route I was initially trained on in those 3 days was constantly expanding. Because of this for 2 weeks I never felt like I was getting a handle on things, and the volume of packages increased (240 pkgs, 130 stops per day). Finally, one day they put my route 15 miles apart in a town I'd never driven in before, and the other half was (15 miles away). During that same day, they chose to pull me to the middle of the two locations off my route to pick up about 5 more packages that could have been way more easily delivered by the man that gave them to me as the location was right there.

I worked 12-13hr days everyday for 3 weeks, with a 20 min break if I was lucky. If you finally found the house, good luck finding the package because the sorting was so horrible nothing was ever where it was suppose to be, and especially after you drove, everything would fall on the ground so much that you couldn't even walk through the truck. And I was really careful with driving, didn't matter it still happened.

HR promised multiple times in the initial info session that if you show up and are ready for work everyday, they will give you a $150 bonus/week. That was never once on my check. I would take the time to commute all the way there (45min in traffic) only to be sent home (usually on mondays) because there was no work.

At the end of your part time work if you choose to take this position, they will lay you off (3 months), and try to get you to be a night shift package handler, and then if you're lucky you get hired back again as a PT driver, but then you get laid off again after another 3 months. This cycle went on for at least 2 years for most of the people I spoke with until anyone saw FT work.

You also receive no health benefits until FT, and are risking your life, your body, and your sanity everyday.

I honestly got to the point where I wasn't bad, but just sat there thinking, this is the toughest job I've ever had, and what's the point?

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in New Stanton, PA
pros:
Many shifts available.  Extra work hours available if willing to pick up extra hours. 
Currently at New Stanton Hub and have found it to be a professionally run warehouse full of employees with various years of service from new to 10, 20 and 30 years.  If you are willing to work they will find a place for you. If your physically not a strong loader they will place you at a job that you feel capeable of doing. I have been pleasantly and fairly treated. Management is  helpful and respectful even upper management knew new hires by their first name after being there days.  I was caught off gaurd that someone who oversees 500+ employees that change often takes time to learn the names of their people and call them by name. Kudos to the New Stanton Hub for being a place I feel proud to be a part of.  
Bonus for holiday employees but onky NEW employees.
cons:
Somewhat of a dangerous job that is repetitive.  I felt sonewhat prepared for what I would be doing, however it should more clearly be told that during peak season the rules change.  It would have made it easier to find childcare if I knew I was expected to start 2 1/2 hours earlier in December. 
The holiday bonus for new hires is a great incentive that also cause friction with long time employees. Would it be so bad to provide holiday bonus for staff even if it were a graduated structure as in so much per week per years of service?  It seems wrong that people who are higher performers arent incentivized fir tough peak season

pros:
•	Amazing Benefits - You'll be hard-pressed to find a company with better benefits.
	•	Job Security - When we went through a recession, you'll still get about 75% of the hours before the recession. Also, you are part of a union and that will make it mission impossible for them to fire you. You basically need to go apeshit to lose your job. 
	•	Tuition Reimbursement - I took advantage of this program and was able to get half of my undergrad paid for. 
	•	Pay Is Not Bad - Once you get some seniority, you'll start to make pretty good money even without a college education. 
	•	It's a very structured and methodical company
cons:
•	Difficult Beginnings - When you just get started with the company, you'll start out at about minimum wage and will be getting very few hours/Wk.
	•	Hard Laboring Work - It's hard on your body as you'll get older! If you don't have a good work ethic, you are lazy or like things easy, and have a lack of disciplined or you are not mentally strong, you will suffer and probably won't last for long. If you don't last for long, you will not realize all the good stuff the company has to offer. There is a lot of good stuff!
	•	Management Vs. Hourly Employee Battle - Just like star wars, it's the never-ending saga! Management (The Dark Side) will push production and they will be on you like white on rice! It's a very production driven company.
	•	December Will Suck - You'll never get time off or vacation after Thanksgiving. Also, if you are looking to stay with the company, make sure you don't start out as a seasonal employee or in the 4th quarter of the year. You'll need to pass 90 days probation period. So think about it, if you start in that 90-day range from the end of the year, they probably will lay you off right after Christmas (which is when the volume dies down, really dies down) unless you are a Spartan of course (they'll love you if you are one).

job_title: Overnight Air Handler in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Weekely paycheck
10.35/hr
12am to 3am+., although other shifts were available, only the night shift fit into my school schedule.
Monday to Thursday. Decent waiting times (15-30minutes, maybe longer if backed up inside) between actual work, short periods of high paced work. Weekly $100 bonus for attendance. Anything over 5 hours is overtime. Not sweating from slave labor like those poor souls on the belts inside.

Decent discounts to ups marketplace on a lot of things.
cons:
Guaranteed job. Mass hiring events.
Without $100 weekely bonus, job is not worth it. Unless it’s peak you are unlikely to get more than 12-14 hours a week. You can get up to 18 if you work Saturday’s aka lazy day, but you are required to work EVERY Saturday if you choose to work one. Not really worth it IMO. After taxes/fees you still only get around $200, maybe 220. Better to just work your 4 days and walk away with your 160-170. Unless your car is really good on gas and you want to spend every Saturday at the airport.

It seems crazy but there are people making 5-10X as much as you and they don’t do 1/4 the work you do. A lot of people who have been working here for a few years are downright lazy and unproductive.

It’s a shame that people can clock in and grab a tug or van to watch Netflix and sleep barely lifting a finger the entire workweek and get $800-$2300. It’s worse with full timers they could only work 20 hours and get paid for 40 hours.

They’ve begun to assign the waste of space known as full timers to little tasks, but nothing can be done about the part time guys making $20-50/hr sleeping through work. Downsides of union.

It wouldn’t be bad if we made a little more money

pros:
As a package car driver, the money is great once you get to 16 months. Not many firms will pay this as an hourly rate. 
Plenty of overtime available inc Saturdays. 
Driver training is available
cons:
Most of the buildings UPS own don’t have modern up to date washing facilities. No showers and/or drying rooms. Cycling to work is not really supported. 
The management WILL BULLY YOU to stay out and deliver. They have no compassion for anything outside of the business. 
A Family and a home life do not exist when working as a package car driver, unless you stick to your guns. The 9 1/2 hour forms are magical. Ask your shop steward for one.  
Progression to more senior positions will never happen. They will promise you everything, but the reality is it’s not going to happen. They’d rather move someone from another centre to backfill then give someone the opportunity. 
The UPS rule book will only apply when you’ve done something wrong (even a mistake) the management don’t follow it unless challenged. 
The company is still very much in the dark ages. Still doing everything by paper, old technology and no lateral thinking. 
They will hound you via your OWN personal mobile phone (which they won’t pay for or provide one to you) whilst working, even when on the No Call List. 
Drivers are not incentivised, it’s always take take take and no thanks. 
Daily routes will be closed down and the workload will be put on to other drivers just so they hit targets, putting drivers at high risk. 
No discipline

pros:
Union is better. 

Part time pension is provided for those who worked 750 hours for credited 1 year, 550 hours for credited 9 months, and so on. If you want a long term "minimum wage" job , UPS is the job for your future retirement.  

If you work longer while people quit, you get more seniority power in which you are given power over your attendance, position, and time.

You are more likely to make more than supervisor and maybe even the management level if staying in the company. If your supervisor is new, you should have some rights to keep them in line because they don't know every guideline. 

UPS depending on what facility will forgive your lateness but will shun or/and terminate you for not calling in. Not calling in is a major employment reputation. 

Educate them if you are disabled provided that your application is mark as disabled so that they don't argue against you to allows accommodation and more time off privileges, seniority power applied.
cons:
You are going to develop some work related health problems. This is not to ignore the fact that you have to follows all UPS health rules. You will always going to get it even if you are extra careful.

It is hard even if you have the least seniority. 

Anybody who thinking about joining military should apply here first. 

People will quit often. Don't expect to keep some of your friends very long. Every time people quit will automatically help raise your seniority over time - generally working at least within a year or up to 3 will get you on the 2nd page and eventually the first page of the employee seniority roster.

Not for every people who have major position related impaired health problem. This is not to says it isn't for senior and disabled people which is not. UPS will hire disabled people if they are pleasing the diversity quo as they have been fined by the court for discriminating people with disabilities.

cons: You are overworked most of the time.  The starting pay is also very low for such a heavy workload.  It takes a year to get health insurance.

review_title: Easy money as a seasonal worker, just don’t get too comfortable.
pros:
I really liked working as a helper, I wish it wasn’t seasonal. 
A lot of the people that work here are laid back and the work is incredibly easy for the wage you get. You just go in and out of the truck all day.
Working under little supervision was nice. I was lucky enough to get along with my driver. Sometimes he’d buy me lunch or bring water for me.
No strict dress code, just wear the reflective vest they give you.
The people you deliver to are honestly really nice, most are happy to see you because they’re receiving their package. That was a really nice feeling. I delivered to the same neighborhood every day and it was nice to become acquainted with the locals. Some apartment complexes offer free drinks and sometimes people leave snacks at their door steps for us.
There’s always room for overtime too.
We get holidays off. Unpaid.
They will hire ANYONE and can give you an interview within the next day.
cons:
These guys can lay you off whenever you want. 
Its physically demanding, but a guy like me can handle it.
It’s seasonal. They claimed it was from November 1st to January 15 but it was a lot shorter than that. I didn’t get a set route until the middle of November and they laid me off the 22nd of December with little to short notice. Apparently it wasn’t as busy this year.
Communication from the help center is terrible. So much confusion at the beginning when they start giving out routes. It’s almost impossible to contact them unless they call you.
Helpers don’t get holiday pay. It’s the end of the year so drivers are using their remaining sick pay. Those factors hurt my hours the most. Sometimes drivers will be asked to make you go home early.
The only rude people I dealt with were some drivers that I worked with and apartment staff working in the leasing office. They’re very stuck up for some reason.
The hardest places to deliver are apartment complexes hands down. Too many stairs and too many packages to carry on your cart. And sometimes it’s hard to find your way around. Hopefully they have elevators too. 
It’s only stable for about a month. I’d say always have a backup plan if you decide to work as a seasonal helper. Other than that it was a cool gig.

pros: For the most part if you’re a loader, they give you a lot of opportunities for overtime.
cons: The pay is terrible since you’re slaving almost the entire time nonstop w/ a 10 minute break. The management & training is terrible. The facilities are old & outdated. The equipment that’s supposed to help you get your job done doesn’t even work 90% of the time.

pros:

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Folsom, CA
pros:
1.  You're lifting heavy packages and running them up to doorsteps; basically, paid excercise.
2.  Opportunity for advancement: UPS prefers to hire from within. Your HR manager may even have helper experience.
3.  If you show up consistently, you might get assigned a route and start time and never worry about them calling you at awkward times.
4.  Fresh air, never stuck inside.
5.  No real dress code for helpers, bring your best active shoes and wear the helper vest when they give you one.
cons:
1.  You're putting yourself in the way of easily mitigated but persistent danger, i.e. crossing streets, walking down slippery stone driveways. Staying safe requires environmental awareness beyond what they teach you in the training videos.
2.  95% percent of the days will transpire without incident. 5% of the days, a porch pirate steals something you delivered, management tells you to go back and investigate, and now the rest of the day is ruined because of lost time.
3.  "Hell is other people" has never been more true. Turns out that stolen package was a visa/passport, the rightful recipient is very angry because their vacation is cancelled, and they're cussing out your driver and asking for your names while threatening legal action. With all the time you spend on the road, dealing with bad drivers becomes routine. Half this list would be people related if not condensed into one point.
4. Inconsistent hours. You could be done before sunset, but you could just as easily be working until 8 pm on a rainy winter night. It's holiday season, they're hiring you to help with the hardest part of the year.
5.  If you get assigned to a route, and management decides they don't need you on a particular day, they may forget to tell you. They're great at calling you when they need you, otherwise not so much.

review_title: Great starting job for 25 an under
pros: Great starter job for someone without a college degree and or 25 and under.  After four years you'll be topped out at $38.00 an hour with plenty of options or required OT. Excellent benefits.
cons: If you every had any knee, or back issues don't apply.  Unless you are young and physically fit/active this wil burn you out quickly.  Company is all about the bottom line without regards to the overall haelth of employees.

pros:
Part time hours are good if you only want 3 and half hours 
Decent money
cons:
Will be promised the progression and full time but they are just empty promises.

Lack of communication all round

If you do the over time and you're shift is put back on starting they will take the difference from you're over time 

If you are a hard work be prepared to be put in the deep end with busy feeds

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Willow Grove, PA
pros: Pay and benefits are excellent, most employees are some of the hardest working people you'll ever meet. Good amount of camaraderie if you're working with the right people. If you're in college or just finishing high school, this is a great job.
cons: There's a lot so get comfortable; Planning is completely backwards and the higher ups want you to accomplish more with less. Almost everything is broken on a regular basis as far as equipment goes, and when upper management makes a bad call and it affects your area, you are the one that's blamed. Absolutely zero communication, except when you have a bad day numbers wise, in which case get ready for a tongue lashing, despite if you had good performance before. The management environment is clearly political, promotions and perks based on who you're friends with, not your actual performance. Safety is a joke, if OSHA were to go into any warehouse they would have a field day. Sad part is that what I just described is the lesser of two evils, if you work the actual 3am to 9am shift, you're not even a manager, you're just a glorified loader that upper management can toss around like it's nothing. Don't get me started on equipment, assuming you can even get any, I can't even get my hands on a radio each day. The only reason UPS offers part time management any of these benefits and pay is because, if they didn't, no one in their right mind would take the job. If you're able, stick with the union, at least then you'll have someone watching your back (note, my immediate supervisor is one of the best I've worked for, but this is a rare scenario)

review_title: Overwhelming amount of volume for the amount of people working
job_title: Package Handler in Round Rock, TX
pros:
- Potentially amazing benefits (health, tuition) if you can last the 9 months required (i didn't)

- Major holidays off

- Easy to get hired
cons:
The below is my experience as a loader:

- Very hot during the summer, very physical work, extremely fast, and very loud warehouse

- An extremely overwhelming amount of volume for the amount of people working each night. 30k - 60k volume depending on the time of year, with generally about 20 loaders. Sometimes you'll get nothing but the heavier volume which quickly wears you out.

- Management expectations don't line up with UPS safety procedures. They want you to reach a certain PPH (package per hour) which can't really be met without ignoring some of the safety rules or loading rules. Frustrating, especially when managers come in and tell you how to appropriately load (which slows you down when you are already behind)

- Managers and Supervisors constantly move you between trailers to catch up on volume (even when the trailer you're currently working in is already behind), very frustrating.

- Volume being all over the floor and potentially trapping you inside the trailer seems to be quite normal, and most people don't help you at that point unless a supervisor orders them to, also very frustrating.

- They send people home early when it feels like we have the right amount of people for the volume for that night, making the work overwhelming for those who stayed to work.

- [Arguably a con] Job description describes that you generally work between 3.5-4 hours, but in my experience I generally worked 4-5.5 hours

- Break is generally 1-1.5 hours into the shift for about 10-15 minutes, then you work the rest of the night. Doesn't make much sense but their reason is that the package cars don't come in until later so they try to line up our work with the package cars as they return.

review_title: Don't let UPS get your hopes up and demand safer working conditions
job_title: 2019 Peak Season PVD in Gainesville, FL
pros: Lot's of great employees to work with and having the opportunity to improve the Customer Experience every day.  UPS is a place where you can make a difference in people's lives.  They are unionized, so if you are a regular hired you have support.
cons:
Management doesn't help you to get ahead, and communications are poor. UPS hired my van, not me. I made it clear from day one; I was interested in getting hired after Peak Season. I was told if I did an excellent job, it might be possible; no details or goals were provided to determine what was considered a "good job."

So, I drove more miles, delivered more packages, received more customer compliments, never took a day off, and worked more hours than any other Peak Season PVD.  One day I covered four routes and worked more than fifteen hours; I was told to clock out before hitting fourteen hours to avoid UPS getting a DOT violation and add the remaining hours to my timecard the next day.

When 2019 Peak Season ended, I repeatedly asked if I would be considered for full-time employment and finally was told I was the top performer. Still, other perimeters out of my control prevented management from choosing me. I later discovered those perimeters were minority-related, and nothing to do with performance.

I wish UPS management had been forthcoming at the beginning regarding diversity needs. I would have still joined the UPS team for the 2019 season, but I won't have gotten my hopes up, and I likely wouldn't have risked my safety working late into the night driving on roads in rural locations, often without cell service. Or missing essential time with my family during the holidays.

Ironically, I was asked to cover routes in rural areas because another Peak season PVD of color had a gun pulled on him, and they felt it safer for a person not of color.

I tried to reach out to UPS Human Resources about this and several other things; they make it impossible to talk to anyone. They don't provide a number or email address for employees to contact them; you must go through local UPS management if you have issues, including sexual harassment.

As a Navy Veteran and former First Responder, I had high hopes for joining UPS, since they advertise their support for both.  I can only blame myself for dreaming I had a chance since they never hired me, they hired my van.

review_title: Entry level work but you should try to get a better job after a year.
pros: True entry level sales, mail, and shipping experience for other shipping or packing work. You also combine the skills of working with customers along with packing and shipping. They offer higher prices for packing, stamps, office supplies, and moving boxes, but that leads to an almost unparalleled convenience in regards to shipping. Seriously, I know that sounds like a company line but if you need to copy a document, send insured mail, send a weirdly shaped item, and buy stamps all at the same time, the UPS store is very convenient if you're willing to pay a little more. Also at Christmas time if you want to just get all your presents wrapped and out as quickly as possible, the UPS store is a good bet. So if you work there, you gain a lot of experience in the way things are shipped and the best and cheapest ways to get it there, and you can parlay this into a better job. Otherwise, all these conveniences mean that you, as the worker, get all the hassle of a post office, a copy shop, and just a retail store along with having to ship some poor dudes antique baby crib to Alaska for 400 bucks.
cons: The pay is not the best. Also, you feel as if you're competing with UPS itself with higher prices. UPS wants customers to have accounts with them, and these accounts would bypass money going to the UPS Store, which is just a franchise. Also, the UPS Store represents the actions of a much bigger company, like UPS and the US postal service. If these companies screw up a delivery, you as the sales associate receive the full brunt of the customer's dissatisfaction, when you might have done a fine job yourself. And since UPS and the post office are less accessible than some poor slob at the UPS Store, that slob tends to be blamed more readily than a faceless organization, considering the fact that we as sales associates often have to argue with UPS and the post office too.

review_title: If you like to drive, then apply for the job, otherwise look at another career path
pros: They give flexible hours and have good benefits, you work on the week and they give you the weekends
cons: Dealing with all kind of people, some are good, some are very bad. Also, if the market is slow then routes are cut which means less pay

pros: For a part-time job you can't beat the complete health benefits package UPS provides for their package handlers. UPS also has great employee discounts on anything from cars to electronics. Employees get rewarded and acknowledged for safety. If you enjoy working out, the few hours you spend at UPS will be well worth your time.
cons: Working at UPS as a package handler is both mentally and physically tough. The turnover rate for employees is extremely high. Some people will go through a weeks worth of training and only last one day doing the actual work. Full-time management is only interested in numbers and downtime and can usually care less about employee safety. When management pushes an already fast paced job to the limit packages are mistreated and handling practices learned in training are thrown out the door. With the constant pressure put on part-time supervisors by full-time supervisors the work environment is often extremely tense and in many cases very dangerous. There are times where a sorter is often forced to get buried in packages just so that belts do not stop and affect downtime. Sort changes are often given the day of said sort change instead of giving employees a few days notice. There is an extreme lack of communication between part-time supervisors around the hub and more times than not each supervisor only cares about their respective areas and doesn't really care what other parts of the hub are negatively affected by their supervision. Employees are often disrespected by management and each person is constantly reminded just how unvaluable they really are. Not all hubs offer tuition reimbursement for package handlers.

pros:
Management has changed drastically within the past 3 months. To say the least it has improved morale. There seems to be a genuine intent to improve existing conditions and allow employees to be more involved with daily operations. The benefits are as good as advertised and the discounts come in handy with a wide variety of categories. 

The work is not difficult and with the right training, is actually easy. Of course, that depends on which account you work in.

Each department is different but overall the people in the company are helpful, cheerful, and willing to help. There is a team atmosphere that has developed lately.
cons: The most obvious is the pay scale. When you bust your tail for six months and are told that you have reached the highest levels of evaluation seen in years, it brings you back down to earth when you are only compensated with a $.25 raise. In theory, you would have to work 12 years to receive a $3 dollar raise. Considering this company deals with medical supplies, starting out at $10 is almost laughable (and that includes forklift operators). The biggest cons under that were inconsistency in management. That and extreme micromanagement of the managers which to some degree, trickled down to employees. Honestly, this is appearing less with the change in management.

review_title: Initially difficult, and decreases as time goes

cons: Not a very elite group of people, though it's extremely production oriented and proffessional in workmanship, not in communication. Being Union people can be crass and unusually open.

review_title: Great benefits but only in the long run...
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Louisville, KY
pros: UPS is a farm system. The more time with them you have, the more of an asset you'll be. The pay and benefits only come with time. For Union workers It takes 18 months to get insurance for yourself. 24 for dependents. However, the insurance is exceptionally well for the work you do. Perhaps the best insurance in Louisville period. Pay increases with time. 35 to 50 cents every August and February after you have finished your probationary period. Metro College program that can pay for college completely. (Louisville only)
cons:
Very few full-time positions for union or management. Union keeps you employed however, you pay union dues every third Thursday of the month. When you start, you are making paychecks around 80 to 110 dollars a week. You have to pay union initiation and monthly fees that destroys your already painfully small paycheck. Most of the jobs are at night. Most part time and full time supervisors are okay but it is the high upper management who come out of nowhere (Particularly during peak season) and start telling you to change the way you work because they don't work in the trucks and feeders and just look at how it is in the book and demand they you change. There is the book and then there is reality. However, they usually leave after one day. 

Management from part time supervisor and up are not part of the union and therefore, not part of the union. They lose the protection and union insurance. Unless they want to pay 2,000 dollars for it. Part time sups are just glorified quality trainers. However, if you want to work full time professional jobs at UPS, 98% of them have to pay their dues working low pay part time sup jobs. 

Most work areas are loud and provide no ear protection. Only workers who work outside get ear protection. 

Very hard to balance school or second day jobs. Don't rely solely on Metro College to pay for college because if you don't have a loan, grant or other form of payment to make to the school at the beginning of the semester and you fail a class or make a D, UPS won't pay for that class and lots of people doing this fail because they can't handle night shift and day school and UofL or JCC won't allow you to resign for the following semester because of your debt. Back yourself up. You might realize halfway through a semester that you can't handle night shift and school. Choose school by making sure you're still covered with school.

pros: If you work hard and are a good employee you will keep a job. The company provides benefits at reduced cost to part time supervisors. Pay rate is decent for part time management positions so long as you do not have a college degree. Work day is fairly predictable although there can be drastic swings in responsibility at any given moment. Lots of eyes on your work at all times for better or worse. Safety is important to the company. Some of my frustrations may be local as other centers might be better managed from the top down or situations might be different.
cons: Seemingly not much upward potential within the company at this time. The pay rate it mediocre if not sub par if you have a college degree and work in part time management. Dealing with union workers and stewards is a huge PITA at crucial times. The union is more interested in keeping and adding jobs than maintaining an exceptional workforce. Full time management leaves part time management to run operations while they handle drivers for the most part. Prepare to be inundated with paperwork and reports. Company is all about the bottom line for sure, yet they pay out the nose for labor in some circumstances.

review_title: Package Driver Full time in New York, NY
job_title: Delivery Driver in New York, NY
pros: Great salary and benefit. All fellow driver are friendly and helpful.
cons: Long hours avg 10.5 hour daily 5 days a week. Management will tell you to falsifier information everyday, keep a record of it ,will use it against you at a later date. Supervisor will tell you to run your deliveries and pick ups. When you get hurt on job, if you don't to have go to hospital, they will take you to one of their doctor that just look at your injury without X-ray or MRI say you can work tomorrow. job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Lawnside, NJ
pros: The company has a good reputation and the job can be fun if you make it fun.
cons: It's only seasonal ending as soon as the holidays are over, it's on-call so you have to be available all day, and its minimum wage and a very physical job.  How fast a pace is determined by the driver you are working with.

review_title: Definitely not for everyone. Get skills outside of the job. Go to school while at this job.
pros:
I worked at ups for 8 months. Through thanksgiving and Christmas season.

Started at 9.50 (2.00$ above minimum wage) Raises (10.50$ after 3-4 months), get done with work before 10am, workout at work, no experience needed, overtime during holiday season, get to help drivers deliver over the Christmas holiday and see happy kids and people get gifts. Union

Also you are able to work another job because of the schedule or go to school. I would do all three if possible. I say that so that if this job begins to be how it was for me and others you won't feel stuck and skill less. Nothing worse than wanting more than your next breath to get out of a job but feel you can't because your options are so slim because of the lack of skills or education.
cons: Entire year before benefits, have to be clocked in early as 2:30am, stressful, extremely cold or extremely hot, management was preaching safety but their methods and speed of forcing out parcels said otherwise, overworked, hub was understaffed meaning many loaders would have 4-5 trucks where if a few more people were hired everyone would have 3 increasing efficiently and cutting down on misloads. Job made me antisocial and dread human interaction. Management kept me on the edge of violent outburst by their blatant disregard of the workers. They felt they were doing a service at pcms by giving out fruit and Gatorades on Fridays and the occasional one size fits all hat or shirt for not getting a misload.

review_title: You get out of UPS what you put in.

review_title: Seems to be some disconnect between coordinators/supervisors to drivers, driver helpers in the field
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Portland, OR
pros: Very thorough orientation for the seasonal driver helpers, especially regarding safety and honesty.  The HR staff and training supervisors friendly and down-to-earth types.  Well-organized orientation.  Got all my questions answered.
cons:
When it came to actually starting the job, there were some discrepancies between what was said in the orientation vs. what happened in the field.  Here are some examples:  

On the first day, a driver contacted me to tell me when and where to meet him.  I was told the coordinator would contact me the first day to tell me where to report for work.  

Second, the driver did not have my uniform on the truck as I was told.  He had to loan me his jacket that day.  

Third, the driver thought I had completed DIAD training (the hand-helds used to scan packages and get signatures).  He was told driver helpers would know what to do.  He was frustrated I was not trained on it.  Because of time constraints, we worked around this and he scanned packages for me to just deliver.  

The second day on the job, I had a different driver.  I was told in orientation I would be paired with one driver.  Anyway, this driver ended up having my uniform.  Again, we worked around the DIAD system due to time constraints.  This driver was unpleasant to work with and she wanted me to jog through wet leaves and on slippery residential staircases because "I need to hustle".  She was incredibly impatient with me for someone being only the 2nd day on the job.  I almost wanted to end my assignment that day.  I ended up reporting this incident to a supervisor later because the jogging around on slippery surfaces was in direct violation of the safety procedures and the supervisor made it clear that I am never to compromise my safety.  He appreciated my report.  On the third day of work, I was paired with the driver from my first day, which was a relief.

Fourth day on the job, I was paired with yet ANOTHER different driver.  This time, I got a patient, grounded person who took the time to train me on the DIAD.  He was good to work with.  I addressed the driver/helper pairing discrepancy with him and he didn't know what happened but said he and I will be working together for the duration of the season.  Thank goodness.  I hope this will be the case as it's been a frustrating start!

review_title: Physical work, probably not rewarding if you don't have the drive
pros:
• You're going to have to move your body. Some dormant employees may make predictable jokes about the work being comparable to gym workouts. It is not a gym, but it is not a sit down job either.
• If you have high work ethic you will find putting in high effort to be its own reward.
• If you're not a very enterprising person, Teamsters will benefit you in pre-programmed work advancements.
• Earn & Learn is incredible, as well as the medical and vision benefits provided by a part time job.
• Outstanding military respect. You can be hired, join the military, then come back with four years of seniority and have a good shot of becoming a driver.
• Plenty of overtime opportunity.
• Almost exclusively part time work
• I left in 2013, but even then the technology is very good. Employees no longer have to memorize zip codes for their trailer. Zip code knowledge only comes in hand for pick-offs and sorters.
• Look. It's hard for a giant employer to give individual care to each employee. That's why the union is around, to protect you. You can talk to your full timers. At Portland we had open door policy. Show up early to talk to someone if you have issues. The management upstairs cares, whether they are nice or mean, and that is why they are full timers.
cons:
• It's easy to have a bad attitude. Some workers come into the warehouse having already defeated themselves, determined to have a bad day.
• Peak season will provide much more work than there are workers. Despite your best efforts, your trailers, belts, etc will be backed up and jammed.
• After a long period of employment you're going to have a negative relationship with UPS - if you are not driven enough to find yourself a better job.
• Unionized workplace means you're going to be a very long queue to become a driver.
• Again, if you have a bad attitude or are generally an upset person UPS will amplify your dissatisfaction. It is easily regarded as only a job.
• Again, unless you press for more, or stand in a very long seniority queue, this is almost exclusively part time work outside of the peak season. Given the effort you can find better work.
• Many of your co-workers will regard UPS as only a job. They come to work and then leave. Many students do this part time, or other employed individuals looking for a little more cash. A lot of the time, UPS just needs bodies in the warehouse.

I was injured pretty badly on the job 3-4 times; once having 95 lbs of boxes fall on the back of my head resulting in a serious concussion and later finding I suffer retaining memories, repeatative knee bending and lift of packages resulting in patella phemoral syndrome, rotater-cuff tendinitis, and tennis elbow. review_title: Do NOT believe anything you read on their​ Careers website; the information is completely inaccurate.
pros: Supervisors and co-workers were really nice people.
cons:
The job description & videos relating to the Part time Package Handler position are 95% inaccurate. I'm not exaggerating.  For example:
   1.  The job is seasonal, yet it doesn't say anything about being seasonal on the UPS website.
   2.  The job is an on-call position, another very important thing the website fails to mention.
   3.   Occasionally, you may show up to work and be sent home because​ the person who made the schedule "overstaffed."
   4.  The job is only eight weeks in length; it starts around November 15 and ends on January 15.  
   5.  You must wear leather boots.  Steel-toed boots are optional, not required.

And here's some stuff you need to know, but no one tells you; You find out once you're working: 
  1.  You can't take anything in the building with you because there is no place to put anything.  Supervisors encourage employees to stay hydrated, but there's barely enough room for a bottle of water in your actual work area.
  2.  If possible, other than your drink, if the item won't fit in your jeans pocket, then don't bring it in.  (This includes your coat.  Leave it in your car.)

pros: Great professional experience and can open doors to even bigger opportunities, likely outside of company. This role does provide higher visibility to upper management. If you work hard and do a good job you’ll shine but the management roles that open are minimal especially in Richmond, VA (at Freight). Most jobs I would see open up are in ATL, GA so it’s great for people willing to relocate. I’m going to give a 3 out of 5 rating - I truly loved all of the people I worked with and all of my managers, but there’s definitely room for improvement from a previous employee standpoint looking at the company overall (see below).
cons:
In the 5 years I worked there I saw several structural changes and layoffs. The workload as a Pricing Analyst is intense and the demands of the Sales team will keep you more than busy. I feel there is pretty good job security in the Revenue Management dept. but transformation can occur at anytime. The vacation time isn’t ideal for folks with kids (2 weeks until you’ve reached 8 years of employment - on the freight side, small package is a little better), the lack of time off almost encourages folks to just “call in sick” when you’ve used up your vacation time. For those who are honest with a work ethic don’t do that, unfortunately I saw abusers of calling in.
Here is a solution: create a PTO bucket with increased time off combined with vacation and sick time, once it’s used up people have to take leave with no pay. It makes people choose their time a little bit more wisely. Those who don’t call in sick have the leisure of a better work/life balance and can actually use more time for vacation and with family, and those who abuse can call in without pay once they’ve used their time.
I left the company getting more pay with less work, and double the time off (4 weeks!). Unfortunately it seems like there’s just more out there than what Freight was willing to offer.

review_title: Not the worst place to work
pros: UPS, like many companies, believes in promotion from within.  It's the kind of company that you should work for if you're looking for stability or a place where you can work for the rest of your life.  Their benefits package exceeds that of most employers.  They still have a pension plan, which is rare.  In their entire history (since 1907) they have never laid off a management person.  There are plenty of different career tracks that a person can take at UPS to tailor to what you want to do.  They have a good amount of personal time and vacation -- they start all employees with two weeks and five personal days.  There is a great deal of flexibility if you get in the right department.
cons: As far as learning and development, UPS isn't the best place to work because of groupthink.  Most of the management people, even every CEO they've had, moved up the ranks within UPS, which doesn't allow for a broad range of ideas.  Most of the upper management I've encountered are very set in their ways no matter how idiotic.  There is a great deal of hostility because it's a traditional union versus management environment.  Depending on the department, they make take advantage of lower ranking people by giving the same amount of responsibility for much less pay.  There is also some racism and sexism with the older senior management.  There isn't a lot of direction and most of the time it's a "sink or swim" environment.  Many times they promote someone and don't provide the guidance that one would need to succeed.  You may be required to work third shift.

cons: Long hours required. Possible long commutes to extended area buildings with no compensation for the travel. Managers frequently treated less well than the unionized employees.  Middle management not made to feel valued.

cons: You get some slow days where you get literally bored and end up doing tasks that are already done. At least this leaves time for some school work to be done.

review_title: "UPS" not a good place for you
pros:
good benefits
If you don't feel like showing up for work you don't have to and no one will care
cons:
The work environment is dirty and has no climate control.  During the winter some parts of the warehouse have employees working outside, while others work inside.  When it rains, most of the time you're going to get wet.  Since the Union took over, it has become a race of "whoever does the least work for the longest time gets the promotion"
  Communication between management and employees is terrible, employees are constantly confused about the policies to get things done.  Gossiping is a huge problem, along with the single goal of management, which is to get everything done as fast as possible and yell at everyone that doesn't complete your work 45 minutes early everyday.
  Those who are lazy receive the easier jobs with less work, and those that work hard are punished by being put in the areas/trucks with highest volume of packages.   The only reward that diligent workers receive is that management will not trash talk about you behind your back, you won't receive a promotion and you won't be given more hours to work because you work hard.
  After 3 years and 9 months of seniority at UPS, I only received 40 hours of vacation time and 1 sick day.  If you would like time off and you've been with the company more than 3 months, then management will require 2 to 3 months prior notice.  If you just started with the company only 12 hours notice is required for a day off.

review_title: I have met some wonderful people along the way but have been privy to some less than savory business practices.
pros: It's a very diverse company and that means that you get to be exposed to many different kinds of people. I've worked for UPS at three different locations in three different parts of the country in my time here and at each place, I met new interesting people. The people are the biggest pro in my mind. I was given the opportunity at a young age to groom my leadership and communication skills. The wages are either on par or above the industry average depending on your position.
cons: The culture. Up until my ninth year with the company, I bled brown. I loved this company and I loved my job. In my ninth year with the company, the culmination of all the unsavory things that I had witnessed came to a head and I realised that something was not right. That something was the culture. Second would have to be the bureaucracy, it is a massive and the most mundane tasks generally require several levels of approval. Almost no trust is given to frontline management when making general decisions regarding the operations. Obviously, some middle managers have a different mindset and provide a better buffer between upper and lower management but on the whole, this is how it is. Our company likes to remind everyone of the Jim Casey's vision which, if you read our legacy and policy books, you will definitely find appeal in our company. However, we simply do not live by the words that we speak so highly of. All things are secondary to numbers, not results but numbers. We live and die by numbers and with little explanation of the value of these numbers. On the whole, UPS does a great job preaching and a terrible job following through. We claim that people are our most important asset and yet I recall a District Manager saying to me once, "On June 6th, 1983, Jim Casey died and we still made service on packages. Do you know what that means? It means that no one is more important than these packages. We are all replaceable." At the time, I bought into this, but over the years I think that is the wrong message for a company who claims to be about it's people. I would get into the promotion process and the lack of upward mobility for younger aspiring employees, myself not included, but then I fear that I'd be ranting.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Denver, CO

For new employees however, you must wait a year to get health coverage.  Was not that way when I started with the company 21yrs ago.  Also the starting wage is too low for starting hour employees working inside the building.  As of this review $8.50/hr is the starting wage for PT employees.  It may go up to $10/hr as of Aug 1, 2013 if the new contract is passed.  This however is too low in my opinion considering the contract will be for 5 years.  There are practically no FT hourly jobs available at UPS unless you want to be a package car driver.
cons: Horrible management that constantly BULLY and HARASS employees.  Management does not know how to treat their employees with "dignity and respect"  which is clearly provided for in the contract.  The fact that that even has to be in writing in the contract says something about management.  Must have a very thick skin to work at UPS!  New employees do not get health benefits for a year.  Starting wage too low and not allowed to take any time off unless you have a vacation week available to you.

pros: The people are good at what they do, for the most part. The benefits were great, and are still good.

review_title: DONT WASTE YOUR TIME AS A LOADER
job_title: Package Handler in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Paid vacation,free health insurance bundles with dental and optial after a year
cons:
If you have confident with your potential and your luck, take a try and see if you can get the position you want. Otherwise,DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME!!!

1.  In 2-3 hours you'll be loading about 1.2-3k packages,which weights vary from 0lb to 140lbs.Their target for you in the 1st week is loading 250 packages per hour. I'm doing 480 per hour and I get all my joints hurt. But they will only tell you to GET USED TO IT

2.  In summer,it will be about 100-120 F in the trailer. And still you have to keep your fast-pace as normal,while the only door fan is about 50 feet away from you. Like they say,theyalways have people pass out at every summer night.

3.  The paid education is limited for colleague degree or higher,while Walmart and Sam's Club pay technical schools degree.

4. You might be thinking about the driver position when you decide to take this job. Well,they do give you the chance. But they WILL ONLY ASK YOU DRIVE WHEN THEY DON'T HAVE ENOUGH DRIVERS. 

And here is my story: I signed the driver training in the 3rd month in ups. And 1 month later, they called me to join their 40 hrs class,which included classroom training and driving training. When I was driving in the class,the supervisor said nearly nothing about my driving. And then,for the 1st time I drove with a supervisor to deliver the packages, he got on me for EVERY SINGLE THING I DID. So far,I've droven for about 4 hrs since I finished the class in June.

During my class,we ever talked to some current full-time driver.They said it took about 2 yrs to 4 yrs for a part-time driver to become a full-time driver. And that only comes to you when you're the best choice among all the part-time drivers,and no other full-time drivers are available,and no current recruitment plan of drivers. 

So please think about it: To spend 2-4 yrs to get yourself a degree or a license and find a decent job, or to stay in your trailer for 2-4 yrs ,waiting for a position that only god knows when it's going to open.

pros: Great Money. Great Benefits. Plenty of hours if you want them.

Speaking of pre-loader, there is no time to fix their mess before you leave AND get paid for it. You are to do it on your own time and your pre-loader screwing up your load is not considered excusable for falling behind... at least until you bring the Shop Steward in :)Orion is broken. review_title: Hired and was very busy during peak, then it drops off and they don't need you as much
