pros: Benefits, discounts. Great benefits for drivers in particular.
cons: Where do I begin? People weren't getting paid the proper amount because they would run out of hours. For example if you were supposed to work 8 hours and you worked 12. They also don't want to fire anyone because they are so desperate for help and very disorganized. There was a lady there that kept harassing people and she harassed me and I reported her. I was at least the 9th person to report her and she still worked there. The job I currently have I make more money as a part time employee then the supervisors make at ups. On top of that people just chuck fragile packages anywhere they please, I've never seen so much damaged freight. They literally have carts full of spilled and crushed packages. There is also politic problems they say you get benefits based on seniority, but if they like you they ignore that. If they don't like you they will gladly give your position away to someone they just hired. Not to mention alot of authority there treat the job like some kind of cult and panic over little things when they should be more concerned about people getting in fights and coming to work high. On top of that I was shocked that alot of the head supervisors are just so mean spirited. I got the impression that they felt we were beneath them and they always seemed to have something nasty to say. Also the belts we use that the packages slide down are always jammed because there is never enough people to help, you spend a majority of your time unjamming heavy packages in a stuffy hot trailer for 10 to 11 bucks an hour if they remember to pay you....good luck. review_title: I had a 4 star experience that turned into 2 stars as a seasonal driver helper
pros: You apply online and get an interview almost immediately. It seems they hire every one and anyone since they need a lot of help during Christmas season. Pay is a few dollars higher than other seasonal jobs. You get paid weekly. You get paid to exercise. Lose weight in a short time. Flexible hours for the most part. Weekends off unless you volunteer to work over time. If you show good work ethic, most drivers will treat you to lunch. I had fun during my experience.
cons:
You must keep track of your hours and take pictures of time sheets as some how payroll doesn't pay you your correct time. They don't allow seasonal employees to do direct deposit so you have to show up on Fridays at the HUB for your check if you're not working that day. (If you're working, your driver will take you your check which is great!) The HUB in San Antonio, TX is a horrible place to visit because no one knows what they're doing and it can take hours for someone to finally bring your check. Longest I spent was 2.5 hours waiting for my check because no one felt like answering the phone when security was calling to notify we were there for checks. This made me hate having to go pick up my checks, thus a reason why my 4 star experience went down to 3 stars. After Christmas is over, UPS cancels all phone numbers provided to seasonal employees and there is no possible way to get a hold of anyone. You can't even tell them you're available for work and you can no longer ask the status of your check. Once Christmas is over, you are disposable and they show it by how easy they no longer want to be in contact with you.  I tried to make arrangements with them to pick up my check on a different day since I worked a different job on Fridays and it was impossible to do so. The lack of communication as an employee was beyond ridiculous. I understand I was a seasonal employee but the way we were treated at the end wasn't right and the reason it fell to 2 stars. When I went to pick up my last check and turn in my vest, it was a 2 hour wait. I had to tell security to call HR so I can make a complaint about how no one was answering the phones again and how no one was bringing the checks. Within 10 minutes of speaking to HR, someone magically brought me my check. 
Almost all positions are part-time unless you work in customer service which you can't apply to unless you're not a UPS employee.  
As a driver helper, although it was fun way to lose weight, it puts a toll on your body and you can quickly have problems. You must be very careful during work as you have no health insurance working for them as a seasonal employee.

pros:
- Easy work
- Good rate of pay
- Majority of the staff are very friendly
- Relaxed work environment
- Plenty of overtime opportunities
cons:
- The man management is beyond absolutely appalling. Team leaders are not properly trained and this is evident when the place is run like a circus on a daily basis 
- Problems with pay packets happen on a regular basis, including overtime being underpaid, money not being received at all and hours not being properly recorded
- Virtually no human resources department, everything has to be chased through team leaders and supervisors who are unfriendly, unapproachable and just overall very intimidating. When you do speak to them about the issues they are unbelievably unhelpful and patronising
- No opportunity for progression, and when there is, the job is advertised and is usually filled by an outside source
- Staff, in particular agency workers, are treated horrifically e.g. spoken to like children, forced to do tasks that could easily be done by others
- Holiday is allocated in the most ridiculous way possible, with a certain number of spots being given during certain months - no consistency here though as the number of available slots doesn't change as new people start, making it harder and harder to get holiday. Oh and also NO HOLIDAY IN DECEMBER ALLOWED!! How on Earth they're allowed to do that is beyond me but that's how it is 
- I could sit here and write cons all day but there's not enough hours in a day!!!

pros: UPS is over 100 years old, so it is definitely a stable job.  If UPS goes out of business there are probably bigger problems to worry about.  My local management team is pretty good, but that obviously varies among departments.
cons:
It is clear to employees, especially non-union specialists, that UPS couldn't care less if you work there or not.  You are just an employee number to them.  The "benefits" shrink every year while the costs go up.  The "raises" are laughable and the performance of your job MAKES ABSOLUTELY NO DIFFERENCE.  I was always told that if you perform excellent work, you will be rewarded; that if you go above and beyond your job description, you will be rewarded; that if you innovate and create better, more efficient ways of doing things, you will be rewarded.  Not at UPS.  Don't even bother.  I did those things and got a "nice job, employee" from my supervisor, but it did not translate into anything more than a less-than-cost-of-living raise (I'm talking a meager 2% or so every year),  It's pathetic.  You are locked into your payband and that determines what, if any, raise you receive regardless of your performance.

Here is an example of how UPS handles employee dissatisfaction.  Most years they give employees a survey to see how they feel about their job and UPS as a company.  Well, as the benefits for non-union workers kept getting smaller, so did the scores for the survey.  What did UPS do to address to low degree of satisfaction with company benefits?  They removed the benefits questions.  Voila - problem solved.

My advice to anyone looking to take a job at Big Brown is: keep looking.  You will not valued or rewarded; you don't matter; your family doesn't matter.  Just get the boxes to their destination and make sure the stock price stays high.  THAT'S what matters to UPS.

pros:

Good luck.
cons:
No hours. No money.  Lazy managers. Asinine drivers complaining about all the packages you just loaded in.  I have no idea how people do this job for so long, and have no idea how half these people got hired.  You would have to actually want a career with ups to keep at this job. I keep asking the manager and she says she’ll just fix it on the computer.  I don’t really understand what’s going on with that. I’d figure I’d give it a try while looking for something else fulltime. And with that said  I do not plan on doing this for much longer.  It’s not really a bad job it’s just not for everyone. 

My advice to anyone who wants to try this is start this young.  Like right out of highschool or college.

review_title: Understaffing and Censorship Create Unsafe Working Conditions at UPS-Redmond, WA
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Redmond, WA
pros:
• Fast onboarding
• Stable company
• Part-time hours
• Full-time benefits after one year
• Opportunities for advancement	
• Nationwide and international locations
cons:
• A 'look-the-other-way' safety culture creates consistently unsafe working conditions 
• Ambiguous contract language on safety and staffing allows for routine understaffing
• The grievance process alongside the labor union has been slowed down to a crawl
• The CHSP safety program exists but is neither comprehensive nor practiced as written
• A 'delay-deny-defend' strategy leaves many exposed to injury as safety concerns ignored

• The risk of injury from understaffing is assigned to laborers and diminishes safety
• There is no limit to the number of packages or their combined weight that package-handlers are required to handle during a shift even when adequately staffed
• The negative impact on working conditions and the massive increase in the workload assigned to individuals makes understaffing a real problem for package-handlers as it amplifies existing risks while creating new risks and unsafe conditions

• The physical risks generated by large increases in missorts, irregulars dumped in front of ladders, filthy trailer floors with trash and loose material, and blocked pathways are amplified by understaffing and assigned to package-handlers
• These amplified risks may lead to injury and injured package-handlers are then blamed for 'not following the methods' in a safety follow-up that shifts all blame to laborers
• Many package-handlers sustain painful repetitive-use-injuries during understaffing which can be difficult to diagnose, treat, manage and recover from

• Understaffing is profitable as it shifts the cost of high turnover away from the company
• External audits are preannounced and the company ramps up staffing to successfully pass  
• After an audit, staffing dwindles, safety conditions diminish, and risks boost injuries

pros: I started in February 2006,the benefits were pretty good then. cons:
I used to work in the Parsippany NJ hub, so some of this might be confined to just my hub, but many I'm guessing are systemic. 

Very physically demanding job, and as others have said if you work hard you will be taken advantage of because there are way too many lazy employees. After promotion I was supposed stop paying union dues since I wasn't union anymore but it seemed to take them a while to figure that out. One of my biggest issues was with the Union. Don't get me wrong, unions are great and all to make sure that you can't get fired for stupid reasons and you have Protections in case something happens. But as a supervisor it makes it extremely difficult. Employees that intentionally work as slow as possible can do this because the union protects them from getting fired for not performing. This is why the hard workers will get taken advantage of, because the union protects all the lazy ones that won't let us get rid of.

As a supervisor I wasn't supposed to handle any packages except to help an employee lift a heavy package or break a jam, stuff like that. It's actually a union violation for us to do so, which I guess I agree with. Problem was my Supervisors would constantly force me to work and I of course would get caught and get yelled at by the same people making me do the work. 

Now comes the fun part, Safety. UPS constantly preaches working safely, and with the union employees they do an OK job with. As for Supervisors it was horrible. I would constantly be told to walk on moving belts which is very dangerous, and they would also start a belt when they knew I was standing on it breaking a jam, not seeming to care that I could fall over and I could hurt myself on the Belt starts. Even when I would tell them I am on the belt and not to start it until I'm clear, my supervisor would make them start it anyway, and this didn't just happen to me. 

As for pay, as a PT Sup it was OK but they didn't like paying overtime. If I went into ot The FT Supervisors liked to 'adjust' my hours from one pay period to the next to stop from paying ot, and funnily enough they would sometimes forget to give me some of those hours back. I lost a couple grand this way. 


This one I'm hoping was just at my hub but I'm not sure. My fellow PT Supervisors and the FT ones as well treated me like crap. I was verbally and mentally harassed, singled out for doing something wrong when others were allowed to do the same thing. Filing a complaint with HR didn't really help. Anyone who does that is ridiculed behind their back and after a brief period of it getting better it just gets worse. This is ultimately the reason why I quit after 8 years of working there.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Redmond, WA
pros:
• Fast onboarding
• Stable company
• Part-time hours
• Full-time benefits after one year

cons:

• Ambiguous contract language on safety and staffing allows for routine understaffing
• The grievance process alongside the labor union has been slowed down to a crawl
• The CHSP safety program exists but is neither comprehensive nor practiced as written
• A 'delay-deny-defend' strategy leaves many exposed to injury as safety concerns ignored

• The risk of injury from understaffing is assigned to laborers and diminishes safety
• There is no limit to the number of packages or their combined weight that package-handlers are required to handle during a shift even when adequately staffed
• The negative impact on working conditions and the massive increase in the workload assigned to individuals makes understaffing a real problem for package-handlers as it amplifies existing risks while creating new risks and unsafe conditions

• The physical risks generated by large increases in missorts, irregulars dumped in front of ladders, filthy trailer floors with trash and loose material, and blocked pathways are amplified by understaffing and assigned to package-handlers
• These amplified risks may lead to injury and injured package-handlers are then blamed for 'not following the methods' in a safety follow-up that shifts all blame to laborers
• Many package-handlers sustain painful repetitive-use-injuries during understaffing which can be difficult to diagnose, treat, manage and recover from

• Understaffing is profitable as it shifts the cost of high turnover away from the company
• External audits are preannounced and the company ramps up staffing to successfully pass

Lastly, and this one highlights the reason I left the company, it is extremely difficult to move into Full-Time management if you are not a minority or a female. So, if you are a white male who wants to advance in management you had best look elsewhere. During my tenure there it was not uncommon for over qualified white males to sit for years in the promotion pool waiting for opportunities while lesser qualified minorities and females were promoted in a manner of months.

review_title: UPS, a great place for minorities and females!
job_title: Employment Representative in Earth City, MO
pros: The best reasons to work at UPS would definitely be related to the idea of seeing what it is like to work for a company that places an extremely high value on efficiency and technological advances. The company studies literally every single element of the business to ensure things are happening as efficiently as possible. Some examples include: UPS employees all use the same ink pen developed and designed by the companies industrial engineers which opens and closes about a tenth of a second faster than the standard retractable pen, they count the number of steps a driver takes during each stop, and they're willing to spend millions of dollars improving legacy technology.
cons: There are many downsides to working at UPS. First, it is a very difficult working environment to adjust to if you are not already used to a very militaristic working environment. Second, the pace is very fast and every job (from the entry level positions to top management positions) comes with extremely high performance expectations. pros:
Despite being a "mature" company, UPS is growing into other areas of the transportation and logistics industry and there are exciting opportunities for those who can take advantage of them.   The operations divisions are high-intensity, high energy places.  This can be physically and mentally draining with the long hours and the higher and more numerous standards the management is judged by, but it also creates a special kind of camaraderie as well.  
Although the company became public in 1997, there's still a culture of "partnership" between management at the supervisor level and above which is held over from the days when the company was privately held, and management were the only one who held stock in UPS.  UPS is also a very stable company with excellent cash flow.  This typically means if you're the type who wants to work for one company their entire career and not jump around a lot you can still do that here.  The variable labor cost model typically means that UPS doesn't have to resort to layoffs during mild economic downturns.  If you're single or married to a non-working spouse and don't plan to have a family, there are numerous opportunities to advance by relocating to other parts of the company every 4-5 years throughout your career.  
This is a male-dominated company for reasons typically related to the work environment.  UPS does not discriminate against women in any way, but most women simply find that the warehouse environment doesn't suit them.   If you're a woman in entry level management and don't mind a warehouse environment, you will be given every opportunity to succeed and advance as UPS is actively trying to bring more women into its management ranks and retain them.  You'll have to be competent, but frankly, in the current environment here, if you're up against a man with the same qualifications for a promotion, in my opinion, you'll get it.  You'll be encouraged to get on a career track to move ahead quickly unless you explicitly make it known you don't want to do so.
cons:
Driving and inside operations jobs are physically grueling compared with typical jobs.  While your average Marine or construction worker would think it was easy, the majority of the population find it to be one of the toughest things they've ever done, and many can't do it well.  This "truck driver" mentality still extends into management, and though the company has multiple work life balance initiatives, it is difficult to do many operations management jobs properly and work less than 55-60 hours per week.  For the engineers, in can sometimes be difficult to implement operating plans with operations people who work 10-15 hours per week more you do.  The operations management team will feel the engineering team doesn't understand the challenges they face.

Another significant downside for some people is that in order to advance into middle management or beyond you have to be willing to relocate to another area at a moment's notice.  This may have been fine in the Ozzie & Harriet days of one income earner.  Today, it excludes a majority of people who find themselves in two income families where the spouse cannot relocate, or divorced parents who don't want to move their children far from their other parents.

review_title: Strong culture, competitive wages, great training, poor work/life balance.
pros: UPS has a very strong culture of promoting from within. It is very easy to move up in the company if you display good management qualities and can work with people. The compensation plan is geared toward long-term employment and you can definitely raise a family on the salary and stock bonuses provided. Upper management clearly defines your job responsibilities and many opportunities for additional training are available to those wishing to improve themselves.  The corporate culture that surrounds employment at UPS is very strong and gives employees a true sense of purpose. Every employee is well aware of the story of the founder James E. Casey, the man that created UPS in Seattle in 1907.
cons: The hours that employees are required to work can be challenging... especially around the holidays. The expectation is that employees put in 50 hours each week and 60 hours each week during peak season, which lasts from Thanksgiving to Christmas Eve.  The work/life balance is also a major detractor from working at UPS. It is good to receive recognition for a job well done, but there is a cost. The company attempts to increase the quality of life of its employees, but the discussions on work/life balance appear to be just that; discussions. Concerns about brought up by individual employees regarding work/life balance usually fall on deaf ears.
